	kerndeint=thresh=10:map=0:order=0:sharp=0:twoway=0



=item *

Enable additional sharpening:
	
	kerndeint=sharp=1



=item *

Paint processed pixels in white:
	
	kerndeint=map=1


=back



=head2 kirsch

Apply kirsch operator to input video stream.

The filter accepts the following option:


=over 4


=item B<planes>

Set which planes will be processed, unprocessed planes will be copied.
By default value 0xf, all planes will be processed.


=item B<scale>

Set value which will be multiplied with filtered result.


=item B<delta>

Set value which will be added to filtered result.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head2 lagfun


Slowly update darker pixels.

This filter makes short flashes of light appear longer.
This filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<decay>

Set factor for decaying. Default is .95. Allowed range is from 0 to 1.


=item B<planes>

Set which planes to filter. Default is all. Allowed range is from 0 to 15.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head2 lenscorrection


Correct radial lens distortion

This filter can be used to correct for radial distortion as can result from the use
of wide angle lenses, and thereby re-rectify the image. To find the right parameters
one can use tools available for example as part of opencv or simply trial-and-error.
To use opencv use the calibration sample (under samples/cpp) from the opencv sources
and extract the k1 and k2 coefficients from the resulting matrix.

Note that effectively the same filter is available in the open-source tools Krita and
Digikam from the KDE project.

In contrast to the B<vignette> filter, which can also be used to compensate lens errors,
this filter corrects the distortion of the image, whereas B<vignette> corrects the
brightness distribution, so you may want to use both filters together in certain
cases, though you will have to take care of ordering, i.e. whether vignetting should
be applied before or after lens correction.


=head3 Options


The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<cx>

Relative x-coordinate of the focal point of the image, and thereby the center of the
distortion. This value has a range [0,1] and is expressed as fractions of the image
width. Default is 0.5.

=item B<cy>

Relative y-coordinate of the focal point of the image, and thereby the center of the
distortion. This value has a range [0,1] and is expressed as fractions of the image
height. Default is 0.5.

=item B<k1>

Coefficient of the quadratic correction term. This value has a range [-1,1]. 0 means
no correction. Default is 0.

=item B<k2>

Coefficient of the double quadratic correction term. This value has a range [-1,1].
0 means no correction. Default is 0.

=item B<i>

Set interpolation type. Can be C<nearest> or C<bilinear>.
Default is C<nearest>.

=item B<fc>

Specify the color of the unmapped pixels. For the syntax of this option,
check the B<"Color" section in the ffmpeg-utils
manual>. Default color is C<black@0>.

=back


The formula that generates the correction is:

I<r_src> = I<r_tgt> * (1 + I<k1> * (I<r_tgt> / I<r_0>)^2 + I<k2> * (I<r_tgt> / I<r_0>)^4)

where I<r_0> is halve of the image diagonal and I<r_src> and I<r_tgt> are the
distances from the focal point in the source and target images, respectively.


=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head2 lensfun


Apply lens correction via the lensfun library (E<lt>B<http://lensfun.sourceforge.net/>E<gt>).

The C<lensfun> filter requires the camera make, camera model, and lens model
to apply the lens correction. The filter will load the lensfun database and
query it to find the corresponding camera and lens entries in the database. As
long as these entries can be found with the given options, the filter can
perform corrections on frames. Note that incomplete strings will result in the
filter choosing the best match with the given options, and the filter will
output the chosen camera and lens models (logged with level "info"). You must
provide the make, camera model, and lens model as they are required.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<make>

The make of the camera (for example, "Canon"). This option is required.


=item B<model>

The model of the camera (for example, "Canon EOS 100D"). This option is
required.


=item B<lens_model>

The model of the lens (for example, "Canon EF-S 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 IS STM"). This
option is required.


=item B<mode>

The type of correction to apply. The following values are valid options:


=over 4


=item B<vignetting>

Enables fixing lens vignetting.


=item B<geometry>

Enables fixing lens geometry. This is the default.


=item B<subpixel>

Enables fixing chromatic aberrations.


=item B<vig_geo>

Enables fixing lens vignetting and lens geometry.


=item B<vig_subpixel>

Enables fixing lens vignetting and chromatic aberrations.


=item B<distortion>

Enables fixing both lens geometry and chromatic aberrations.


=item B<all>

Enables all possible corrections.


=back


=item B<focal_length>

The focal length of the image/video (zoom; expected constant for video). For
example, a 18--55mm lens has focal length range of [18--55], so a value in that
range should be chosen when using that lens. Default 18.


=item B<aperture>

The aperture of the image/video (expected constant for video). Note that
aperture is only used for vignetting correction. Default 3.5.


=item B<focus_distance>

The focus distance of the image/video (expected constant for video). Note that
focus distance is only used for vignetting and only slightly affects the
vignetting correction process. If unknown, leave it at the default value (which
is 1000).


=item B<scale>

The scale factor which is applied after transformation. After correction the
video is no longer necessarily rectangular. This parameter controls how much of
the resulting image is visible. The value 0 means that a value will be chosen
automatically such that there is little or no unmapped area in the output
image. 1.0 means that no additional scaling is done. Lower values may result
in more of the corrected image being visible, while higher values may avoid
unmapped areas in the output.


=item B<target_geometry>

The target geometry of the output image/video. The following values are valid
options:


=over 4


=item B<rectilinear (default)>


=item B<fisheye>


=item B<panoramic>


=item B<equirectangular>


=item B<fisheye_orthographic>


=item B<fisheye_stereographic>


=item B<fisheye_equisolid>


=item B<fisheye_thoby>


=back


=item B<reverse>

Apply the reverse of image correction (instead of correcting distortion, apply
it).


=item B<interpolation>

The type of interpolation used when correcting distortion. The following values
are valid options:


=over 4


=item B<nearest>


=item B<linear (default)>


=item B<lanczos>


=back


=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Apply lens correction with make "Canon", camera model "Canon EOS 100D", and lens
model "Canon EF-S 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 IS STM" with focal length of "18" and
aperture of "8.0".

	
	ffmpeg -i input.mov -vf lensfun=make=Canon:model="Canon EOS 100D":lens_model="Canon EF-S 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 IS STM":focal_length=18:aperture=8 -c:v h264 -b:v 8000k output.mov



=item *

Apply the same as before, but only for the first 5 seconds of video.

	
	ffmpeg -i input.mov -vf lensfun=make=Canon:model="Canon EOS 100D":lens_model="Canon EF-S 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6 IS STM":focal_length=18:aperture=8:enable='lte(t\,5)' -c:v h264 -b:v 8000k output.mov



=back



=head2 libvmaf


Obtain the VMAF (Video Multi-Method Assessment Fusion)
score between two input videos.

The obtained VMAF score is printed through the logging system.

It requires Netflix's vmaf library (libvmaf) as a pre-requisite.
After installing the library it can be enabled using:
C<./configure --enable-libvmaf>.
If no model path is specified it uses the default model: C<vmaf_v0.6.1.pkl>.

The filter has following options:


=over 4


=item B<model_path>

Set the model path which is to be used for SVM.
Default value: C<"/usr/local/share/model/vmaf_v0.6.1.pkl">


=item B<log_path>

Set the file path to be used to store logs.


=item B<log_fmt>

Set the format of the log file (csv, json or xml).


=item B<enable_transform>

This option can enable/disable the C<score_transform> applied to the final predicted VMAF score,
if you have specified score_transform option in the input parameter file passed to C<run_vmaf_training.py>
Default value: C<false>


=item B<phone_model>

Invokes the phone model which will generate VMAF scores higher than in the
regular model, which is more suitable for laptop, TV, etc. viewing conditions.
Default value: C<false>


=item B<psnr>

Enables computing psnr along with vmaf.
Default value: C<false>


=item B<ssim>

Enables computing ssim along with vmaf.
Default value: C<false>


=item B<ms_ssim>

Enables computing ms_ssim along with vmaf.
Default value: C<false>


=item B<pool>

Set the pool method to be used for computing vmaf.
Options are C<min>, C<harmonic_mean> or C<mean> (default).


=item B<n_threads>

Set number of threads to be used when computing vmaf.
Default value: C<0>, which makes use of all available logical processors.


=item B<n_subsample>

Set interval for frame subsampling used when computing vmaf.
Default value: C<1>


=item B<enable_conf_interval>

Enables confidence interval.
Default value: C<false>

=back


This filter also supports the B<framesync> options.


=head3 Examples


=over 4


=item *

On the below examples the input file F<main.mpg> being processed is
compared with the reference file F<ref.mpg>.

	
	ffmpeg -i main.mpg -i ref.mpg -lavfi libvmaf -f null -



=item *

Example with options:
	
	ffmpeg -i main.mpg -i ref.mpg -lavfi libvmaf="psnr=1:log_fmt=json" -f null -



=item *

Example with options and different containers:
	
	ffmpeg -i main.mpg -i ref.mkv -lavfi "[0:v]settb=AVTB,setpts=PTS-STARTPTS[main];[1:v]settb=AVTB,setpts=PTS-STARTPTS[ref];[main][ref]libvmaf=psnr=1:log_fmt=json" -f null -


=back



=head2 limiter


Limits the pixel components values to the specified range [min, max].

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<min>

Lower bound. Defaults to the lowest allowed value for the input.


=item B<max>

Upper bound. Defaults to the highest allowed value for the input.


=item B<planes>

Specify which planes will be processed. Defaults to all available.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head2 loop


Loop video frames.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<loop>

Set the number of loops. Setting this value to -1 will result in infinite loops.
Default is 0.


=item B<size>

Set maximal size in number of frames. Default is 0.


=item B<start>

Set first frame of loop. Default is 0.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Loop single first frame infinitely:
	
	loop=loop=-1:size=1:start=0



=item *

Loop single first frame 10 times:
	
	loop=loop=10:size=1:start=0



=item *

Loop 10 first frames 5 times:
	
	loop=loop=5:size=10:start=0


=back



=head2 lut1d


Apply a 1D LUT to an input video.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<file>

Set the 1D LUT file name.

Currently supported formats:

=over 4


=item B<cube>

Iridas

=item B<csp>

cineSpace

=back



=item B<interp>

Select interpolation mode.

Available values are:


=over 4


=item B<nearest>

Use values from the nearest defined point.

=item B<linear>

Interpolate values using the linear interpolation.

=item B<cosine>

Interpolate values using the cosine interpolation.

=item B<cubic>

Interpolate values using the cubic interpolation.

=item B<spline>

Interpolate values using the spline interpolation.

=back


=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.



=head2 lut3d


Apply a 3D LUT to an input video.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<file>

Set the 3D LUT file name.

Currently supported formats:

=over 4


=item B<3dl>

AfterEffects

=item B<cube>

Iridas

=item B<dat>

DaVinci

=item B<m3d>

Pandora

=item B<csp>

cineSpace

=back


=item B<interp>

Select interpolation mode.

Available values are:


=over 4


=item B<nearest>

Use values from the nearest defined point.

=item B<trilinear>

Interpolate values using the 8 points defining a cube.

=item B<tetrahedral>

Interpolate values using a tetrahedron.

=item B<pyramid>

Interpolate values using a pyramid.

=item B<prism>

Interpolate values using a prism.

=back


=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the C<interp> option as B<commands>.


=head2 lumakey


Turn certain luma values into transparency.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<threshold>

Set the luma which will be used as base for transparency.
Default value is C<0>.


=item B<tolerance>

Set the range of luma values to be keyed out.
Default value is C<0.01>.


=item B<softness>

Set the range of softness. Default value is C<0>.
Use this to control gradual transition from zero to full transparency.

=back



=head3 Commands

This filter supports same B<commands> as options.
The command accepts the same syntax of the corresponding option.

If the specified expression is not valid, it is kept at its current
value.


=head2 lut, lutrgb, lutyuv


Compute a look-up table for binding each pixel component input value
to an output value, and apply it to the input video.

I<lutyuv> applies a lookup table to a YUV input video, I<lutrgb>
to an RGB input video.

These filters accept the following parameters:

=over 4


=item B<c0>

set first pixel component expression

=item B<c1>

set second pixel component expression

=item B<c2>

set third pixel component expression

=item B<c3>

set fourth pixel component expression, corresponds to the alpha component


=item B<r>

set red component expression

=item B<g>

set green component expression

=item B<b>

set blue component expression

=item B<a>

alpha component expression


=item B<y>

set Y/luminance component expression

=item B<u>

set U/Cb component expression

=item B<v>

set V/Cr component expression

=back


Each of them specifies the expression to use for computing the lookup table for
the corresponding pixel component values.

The exact component associated to each of the I<c*> options depends on the
format in input.

The I<lut> filter requires either YUV or RGB pixel formats in input,
I<lutrgb> requires RGB pixel formats in input, and I<lutyuv> requires YUV.

The expressions can contain the following constants and functions:


=over 4


=item B<w>


=item B<h>

The input width and height.


=item B<val>

The input value for the pixel component.


=item B<clipval>

The input value, clipped to the I<minval>-I<maxval> range.


=item B<maxval>

The maximum value for the pixel component.


=item B<minval>

The minimum value for the pixel component.


=item B<negval>

The negated value for the pixel component value, clipped to the
I<minval>-I<maxval> range; it corresponds to the expression
"maxval-clipval+minval".


=item B<clip(val)>

The computed value in I<val>, clipped to the
I<minval>-I<maxval> range.


=item B<gammaval(gamma)>

The computed gamma correction value of the pixel component value,
clipped to the I<minval>-I<maxval> range. It corresponds to the
expression
"pow((clipval-minval)/(maxval-minval)\,I<gamma>)*(maxval-minval)+minval"


=back


All expressions default to "val".


=head3 Commands


This filter supports same B<commands> as options.


=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Negate input video:
	
	lutrgb="r=maxval+minval-val:g=maxval+minval-val:b=maxval+minval-val"
	lutyuv="y=maxval+minval-val:u=maxval+minval-val:v=maxval+minval-val"


The above is the same as:
	
	lutrgb="r=negval:g=negval:b=negval"
	lutyuv="y=negval:u=negval:v=negval"



=item *

Negate luminance:
	
	lutyuv=y=negval



=item *

Remove chroma components, turning the video into a graytone image:
	
	lutyuv="u=128:v=128"



=item *

Apply a luma burning effect:
	
	lutyuv="y=2*val"



=item *

Remove green and blue components:
	
	lutrgb="g=0:b=0"



=item *

Set a constant alpha channel value on input:
	
	format=rgba,lutrgb=a="maxval-minval/2"



=item *

Correct luminance gamma by a factor of 0.5:
	
	lutyuv=y=gammaval(0.5)



=item *

Discard least significant bits of luma:
	
	lutyuv=y='bitand(val, 128+64+32)'



=item *

Technicolor like effect:
	
	lutyuv=u='(val-maxval/2)*2+maxval/2':v='(val-maxval/2)*2+maxval/2'


=back



=head2 lut2, tlut2


The C<lut2> filter takes two input streams and outputs one
stream.

The C<tlut2> (time lut2) filter takes two consecutive frames
from one single stream.

This filter accepts the following parameters:

=over 4


=item B<c0>

set first pixel component expression

=item B<c1>

set second pixel component expression

=item B<c2>

set third pixel component expression

=item B<c3>

set fourth pixel component expression, corresponds to the alpha component


=item B<d>

set output bit depth, only available for C<lut2> filter. By default is 0,
which means bit depth is automatically picked from first input format.

=back


The C<lut2> filter also supports the B<framesync> options.

Each of them specifies the expression to use for computing the lookup table for
the corresponding pixel component values.

The exact component associated to each of the I<c*> options depends on the
format in inputs.

The expressions can contain the following constants:


=over 4


=item B<w>


=item B<h>

The input width and height.


=item B<x>

The first input value for the pixel component.


=item B<y>

The second input value for the pixel component.


=item B<bdx>

The first input video bit depth.


=item B<bdy>

The second input video bit depth.

=back


All expressions default to "x".


=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands> except option C<d>.


=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Highlight differences between two RGB video streams:
	
	lut2='ifnot(x-y,0,pow(2,bdx)-1):ifnot(x-y,0,pow(2,bdx)-1):ifnot(x-y,0,pow(2,bdx)-1)'



=item *

Highlight differences between two YUV video streams:
	
	lut2='ifnot(x-y,0,pow(2,bdx)-1):ifnot(x-y,pow(2,bdx-1),pow(2,bdx)-1):ifnot(x-y,pow(2,bdx-1),pow(2,bdx)-1)'



=item *

Show max difference between two video streams:
	
	lut2='if(lt(x,y),0,if(gt(x,y),pow(2,bdx)-1,pow(2,bdx-1))):if(lt(x,y),0,if(gt(x,y),pow(2,bdx)-1,pow(2,bdx-1))):if(lt(x,y),0,if(gt(x,y),pow(2,bdx)-1,pow(2,bdx-1)))'


=back



=head2 maskedclamp


Clamp the first input stream with the second input and third input stream.

Returns the value of first stream to be between second input
stream - C<undershoot> and third input stream + C<overshoot>.

This filter accepts the following options:

=over 4


=item B<undershoot>

Default value is C<0>.


=item B<overshoot>

Default value is C<0>.


=item B<planes>

Set which planes will be processed as bitmap, unprocessed planes will be
copied from first stream.
By default value 0xf, all planes will be processed.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head2 maskedmax


Merge the second and third input stream into output stream using absolute differences
between second input stream and first input stream and absolute difference between
third input stream and first input stream. The picked value will be from second input
stream if second absolute difference is greater than first one or from third input stream
otherwise.

This filter accepts the following options:

=over 4


=item B<planes>

Set which planes will be processed as bitmap, unprocessed planes will be
copied from first stream.
By default value 0xf, all planes will be processed.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head2 maskedmerge


Merge the first input stream with the second input stream using per pixel
weights in the third input stream.

A value of 0 in the third stream pixel component means that pixel component
from first stream is returned unchanged, while maximum value (eg. 255 for
8-bit videos) means that pixel component from second stream is returned
unchanged. Intermediate values define the amount of merging between both
input stream's pixel components.

This filter accepts the following options:

=over 4


=item B<planes>

Set which planes will be processed as bitmap, unprocessed planes will be
copied from first stream.
By default value 0xf, all planes will be processed.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head2 maskedmin


Merge the second and third input stream into output stream using absolute differences
between second input stream and first input stream and absolute difference between
third input stream and first input stream. The picked value will be from second input
stream if second absolute difference is less than first one or from third input stream
otherwise.

This filter accepts the following options:

=over 4


=item B<planes>

Set which planes will be processed as bitmap, unprocessed planes will be
copied from first stream.
By default value 0xf, all planes will be processed.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head2 maskedthreshold

Pick pixels comparing absolute difference of two video streams with fixed
threshold.

If absolute difference between pixel component of first and second video
stream is equal or lower than user supplied threshold than pixel component
from first video stream is picked, otherwise pixel component from second
video stream is picked.

This filter accepts the following options:

=over 4


=item B<threshold>

Set threshold used when picking pixels from absolute difference from two input
video streams.


=item B<planes>

Set which planes will be processed as bitmap, unprocessed planes will be
copied from second stream.
By default value 0xf, all planes will be processed.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head2 maskfun

Create mask from input video.

For example it is useful to create motion masks after C<tblend> filter.

This filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<low>

Set low threshold. Any pixel component lower or exact than this value will be set to 0.


=item B<high>

Set high threshold. Any pixel component higher than this value will be set to max value
allowed for current pixel format.


=item B<planes>

Set planes to filter, by default all available planes are filtered.


=item B<fill>

Fill all frame pixels with this value.


=item B<sum>

Set max average pixel value for frame. If sum of all pixel components is higher that this
average, output frame will be completely filled with value set by I<fill> option.
Typically useful for scene changes when used in combination with C<tblend> filter.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head2 mcdeint


Apply motion-compensation deinterlacing.

It needs one field per frame as input and must thus be used together
with yadif=1/3 or equivalent.

This filter accepts the following options:

=over 4


=item B<mode>

Set the deinterlacing mode.

It accepts one of the following values:

=over 4


=item B<fast>


=item B<medium>


=item B<slow>

use iterative motion estimation

=item B<extra_slow>

like B<slow>, but use multiple reference frames.

=back

Default value is B<fast>.


=item B<parity>

Set the picture field parity assumed for the input video. It must be
one of the following values:


=over 4


=item B<0, tff>

assume top field first

=item B<1, bff>

assume bottom field first

=back


Default value is B<bff>.


=item B<qp>

Set per-block quantization parameter (QP) used by the internal
encoder.

Higher values should result in a smoother motion vector field but less
optimal individual vectors. Default value is 1.

=back



=head2 median


Pick median pixel from certain rectangle defined by radius.

This filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<radius>

Set horizontal radius size. Default value is C<1>.
Allowed range is integer from 1 to 127.


=item B<planes>

Set which planes to process. Default is C<15>, which is all available planes.


=item B<radiusV>

Set vertical radius size. Default value is C<0>.
Allowed range is integer from 0 to 127.
If it is 0, value will be picked from horizontal C<radius> option.


=item B<percentile>

Set median percentile. Default value is C<0.5>.
Default value of C<0.5> will pick always median values, while C<0> will pick
minimum values, and C<1> maximum values.

=back



=head3 Commands

This filter supports same B<commands> as options.
The command accepts the same syntax of the corresponding option.

If the specified expression is not valid, it is kept at its current
value.


=head2 mergeplanes


Merge color channel components from several video streams.

The filter accepts up to 4 input streams, and merge selected input
planes to the output video.

This filter accepts the following options:

=over 4


=item B<mapping>

Set input to output plane mapping. Default is C<0>.

The mappings is specified as a bitmap. It should be specified as a
hexadecimal number in the form 0xAa[Bb[Cc[Dd]]]. 'Aa' describes the
mapping for the first plane of the output stream. 'A' sets the number of
the input stream to use (from 0 to 3), and 'a' the plane number of the
corresponding input to use (from 0 to 3). The rest of the mappings is
similar, 'Bb' describes the mapping for the output stream second
plane, 'Cc' describes the mapping for the output stream third plane and
'Dd' describes the mapping for the output stream fourth plane.


=item B<format>

Set output pixel format. Default is C<yuva444p>.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Merge three gray video streams of same width and height into single video stream:
	
	[a0][a1][a2]mergeplanes=0x001020:yuv444p



=item *

Merge 1st yuv444p stream and 2nd gray video stream into yuva444p video stream:
	
	[a0][a1]mergeplanes=0x00010210:yuva444p



=item *

Swap Y and A plane in yuva444p stream:
	
	format=yuva444p,mergeplanes=0x03010200:yuva444p



=item *

Swap U and V plane in yuv420p stream:
	
	format=yuv420p,mergeplanes=0x000201:yuv420p



=item *

Cast a rgb24 clip to yuv444p:
	
	format=rgb24,mergeplanes=0x000102:yuv444p


=back



=head2 mestimate


Estimate and export motion vectors using block matching algorithms.
Motion vectors are stored in frame side data to be used by other filters.

This filter accepts the following options:

=over 4


=item B<method>

Specify the motion estimation method. Accepts one of the following values:


=over 4


=item B<esa>

Exhaustive search algorithm.

=item B<tss>

Three step search algorithm.

=item B<tdls>

Two dimensional logarithmic search algorithm.

=item B<ntss>

New three step search algorithm.

=item B<fss>

Four step search algorithm.

=item B<ds>

Diamond search algorithm.

=item B<hexbs>

Hexagon-based search algorithm.

=item B<epzs>

Enhanced predictive zonal search algorithm.

=item B<umh>

Uneven multi-hexagon search algorithm.

=back

Default value is B<esa>.


=item B<mb_size>

Macroblock size. Default C<16>.


=item B<search_param>

Search parameter. Default C<7>.

=back



=head2 midequalizer


Apply Midway Image Equalization effect using two video streams.

Midway Image Equalization adjusts a pair of images to have the same
histogram, while maintaining their dynamics as much as possible. It's
useful for e.g. matching exposures from a pair of stereo cameras.

This filter has two inputs and one output, which must be of same pixel format, but
may be of different sizes. The output of filter is first input adjusted with
midway histogram of both inputs.

This filter accepts the following option:


=over 4


=item B<planes>

Set which planes to process. Default is C<15>, which is all available planes.

=back



=head2 minterpolate


Convert the video to specified frame rate using motion interpolation.

This filter accepts the following options:

=over 4


=item B<fps>

Specify the output frame rate. This can be rational e.g. C<60000/1001>. Frames are dropped if I<fps> is lower than source fps. Default C<60>.


=item B<mi_mode>

Motion interpolation mode. Following values are accepted:

=over 4


=item B<dup>

Duplicate previous or next frame for interpolating new ones.

=item B<blend>

Blend source frames. Interpolated frame is mean of previous and next frames.

=item B<mci>

Motion compensated interpolation. Following options are effective when this mode is selected:


=over 4


=item B<mc_mode>

Motion compensation mode. Following values are accepted:

=over 4


=item B<obmc>

Overlapped block motion compensation.

=item B<aobmc>

Adaptive overlapped block motion compensation. Window weighting coefficients are controlled adaptively according to the reliabilities of the neighboring motion vectors to reduce oversmoothing.

=back

Default mode is B<obmc>.


=item B<me_mode>

Motion estimation mode. Following values are accepted:

=over 4


=item B<bidir>

Bidirectional motion estimation. Motion vectors are estimated for each source frame in both forward and backward directions.

=item B<bilat>

Bilateral motion estimation. Motion vectors are estimated directly for interpolated frame.

=back

Default mode is B<bilat>.


=item B<me>

The algorithm to be used for motion estimation. Following values are accepted:

=over 4


=item B<esa>

Exhaustive search algorithm.

=item B<tss>

Three step search algorithm.

=item B<tdls>

Two dimensional logarithmic search algorithm.

=item B<ntss>

New three step search algorithm.

=item B<fss>

Four step search algorithm.

=item B<ds>

Diamond search algorithm.

=item B<hexbs>

Hexagon-based search algorithm.

=item B<epzs>

Enhanced predictive zonal search algorithm.

=item B<umh>

Uneven multi-hexagon search algorithm.

=back

Default algorithm is B<epzs>.


=item B<mb_size>

Macroblock size. Default C<16>.


=item B<search_param>

Motion estimation search parameter. Default C<32>.


=item B<vsbmc>

Enable variable-size block motion compensation. Motion estimation is applied with smaller block sizes at object boundaries in order to make the them less blur. Default is C<0> (disabled).

=back


=back



=item B<scd>

Scene change detection method. Scene change leads motion vectors to be in random direction. Scene change detection replace interpolated frames by duplicate ones. May not be needed for other modes. Following values are accepted:

=over 4


=item B<none>

Disable scene change detection.

=item B<fdiff>

Frame difference. Corresponding pixel values are compared and if it satisfies I<scd_threshold> scene change is detected.

=back

Default method is B<fdiff>.


=item B<scd_threshold>

Scene change detection threshold. Default is C<10.>.

=back



=head2 mix


Mix several video input streams into one video stream.

A description of the accepted options follows.


=over 4


=item B<nb_inputs>

The number of inputs. If unspecified, it defaults to 2.


=item B<weights>

Specify weight of each input video stream as sequence.
Each weight is separated by space. If number of weights
is smaller than number of I<frames> last specified
weight will be used for all remaining unset weights.


=item B<scale>

Specify scale, if it is set it will be multiplied with sum
of each weight multiplied with pixel values to give final destination
pixel value. By default I<scale> is auto scaled to sum of weights.


=item B<duration>

Specify how end of stream is determined.

=over 4


=item B<longest>

The duration of the longest input. (default)


=item B<shortest>

The duration of the shortest input.


=item B<first>

The duration of the first input.

=back


=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the following commands:

=over 4


=item B<weights>


=item B<scale>

Syntax is same as option with same name.

=back



=head2 monochrome

Convert video to gray using custom color filter.

A description of the accepted options follows.


=over 4


=item B<cb>

Set the chroma blue spot. Allowed range is from -1 to 1.
Default value is 0.


=item B<cr>

Set the chroma red spot. Allowed range is from -1 to 1.
Default value is 0.


=item B<size>

Set the color filter size. Allowed range is from .1 to 10.
Default value is 1.


=item B<high>

Set the highlights strength. Allowed range is from 0 to 1.
Default value is 0.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head2 mpdecimate


Drop frames that do not differ greatly from the previous frame in
order to reduce frame rate.

The main use of this filter is for very-low-bitrate encoding
(e.g. streaming over dialup modem), but it could in theory be used for
fixing movies that were inverse-telecined incorrectly.

A description of the accepted options follows.


=over 4


=item B<max>

Set the maximum number of consecutive frames which can be dropped (if
positive), or the minimum interval between dropped frames (if
negative). If the value is 0, the frame is dropped disregarding the
number of previous sequentially dropped frames.

Default value is 0.


=item B<hi>


=item B<lo>


=item B<frac>

Set the dropping threshold values.

Values for B<hi> and B<lo> are for 8x8 pixel blocks and
represent actual pixel value differences, so a threshold of 64
corresponds to 1 unit of difference for each pixel, or the same spread
out differently over the block.

A frame is a candidate for dropping if no 8x8 blocks differ by more
than a threshold of B<hi>, and if no more than B<frac> blocks (1
meaning the whole image) differ by more than a threshold of B<lo>.

Default value for B<hi> is 64*12, default value for B<lo> is
64*5, and default value for B<frac> is 0.33.

=back



=head2 msad


Obtain the MSAD (Mean Sum of Absolute Differences) between two input videos.

This filter takes two input videos.

Both input videos must have the same resolution and pixel format for
this filter to work correctly. Also it assumes that both inputs
have the same number of frames, which are compared one by one.

The obtained per component, average, min and max MSAD is printed through
the logging system.

The filter stores the calculated MSAD of each frame in frame metadata.

In the below example the input file F<main.mpg> being processed is compared
with the reference file F<ref.mpg>.

	
	ffmpeg -i main.mpg -i ref.mpg -lavfi msad -f null -



=head2 negate


Negate (invert) the input video.

It accepts the following option:


=over 4



=item B<negate_alpha>

With value 1, it negates the alpha component, if present. Default value is 0.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports same B<commands> as options.



=head2 nlmeans


Denoise frames using Non-Local Means algorithm.

Each pixel is adjusted by looking for other pixels with similar contexts. This
context similarity is defined by comparing their surrounding patches of size
B<p>xB<p>. Patches are searched in an area of B<r>xB<r>
around the pixel.

Note that the research area defines centers for patches, which means some
patches will be made of pixels outside that research area.

The filter accepts the following options.


=over 4


=item B<s>

Set denoising strength. Default is 1.0. Must be in range [1.0, 30.0].


=item B<p>

Set patch size. Default is 7. Must be odd number in range [0, 99].


=item B<pc>

Same as B<p> but for chroma planes.

The default value is I<0> and means automatic.


=item B<r>

Set research size. Default is 15. Must be odd number in range [0, 99].


=item B<rc>

Same as B<r> but for chroma planes.

The default value is I<0> and means automatic.

=back



=head2 nnedi


Deinterlace video using neural network edge directed interpolation.

This filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<weights>

Mandatory option, without binary file filter can not work.
Currently file can be found here:
https://github.com/dubhater/vapoursynth-nnedi3/blob/master/src/nnedi3_weights.bin


=item B<deint>

Set which frames to deinterlace, by default it is C<all>.
Can be C<all> or C<interlaced>.


=item B<field>

Set mode of operation.

Can be one of the following:


=over 4


=item B<af>

Use frame flags, both fields.

=item B<a>

Use frame flags, single field.

=item B<t>

Use top field only.

=item B<b>

Use bottom field only.

=item B<tf>

Use both fields, top first.

=item B<bf>

Use both fields, bottom first.

=back



=item B<planes>

Set which planes to process, by default filter process all frames.


=item B<nsize>

Set size of local neighborhood around each pixel, used by the predictor neural
network.

Can be one of the following:


=over 4


=item B<s8x6>


=item B<s16x6>


=item B<s32x6>


=item B<s48x6>


=item B<s8x4>


=item B<s16x4>


=item B<s32x4>


=back



=item B<nns>

Set the number of neurons in predictor neural network.
Can be one of the following:


=over 4


=item B<n16>


=item B<n32>


=item B<n64>


=item B<n128>


=item B<n256>


=back



=item B<qual>

Controls the number of different neural network predictions that are blended
together to compute the final output value. Can be C<fast>, default or
C<slow>.


=item B<etype>

Set which set of weights to use in the predictor.
Can be one of the following:


=over 4


=item B<a, abs>

weights trained to minimize absolute error

=item B<s, mse>

weights trained to minimize squared error

=back



=item B<pscrn>

Controls whether or not the prescreener neural network is used to decide
which pixels should be processed by the predictor neural network and which
can be handled by simple cubic interpolation.
The prescreener is trained to know whether cubic interpolation will be
sufficient for a pixel or whether it should be predicted by the predictor nn.
The computational complexity of the prescreener nn is much less than that of
the predictor nn. Since most pixels can be handled by cubic interpolation,
using the prescreener generally results in much faster processing.
The prescreener is pretty accurate, so the difference between using it and not
using it is almost always unnoticeable.

Can be one of the following:


=over 4


=item B<none>


=item B<original>


=item B<new>


=item B<new2>


=item B<new3>


=back


Default is C<new>.

=back



=head3 Commands

This filter supports same B<commands> as options, excluding I<weights> option.


=head2 noformat


Force libavfilter not to use any of the specified pixel formats for the
input to the next filter.

It accepts the following parameters:

=over 4



=item B<pix_fmts>

A '|'-separated list of pixel format names, such as
pix_fmts=yuv420p|monow|rgb24".


=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Force libavfilter to use a format different from I<yuv420p> for the
input to the vflip filter:
	
	noformat=pix_fmts=yuv420p,vflip



=item *

Convert the input video to any of the formats not contained in the list:
	
	noformat=yuv420p|yuv444p|yuv410p


=back



=head2 noise


Add noise on video input frame.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<all_seed>


=item B<c0_seed>


=item B<c1_seed>


=item B<c2_seed>


=item B<c3_seed>

Set noise seed for specific pixel component or all pixel components in case
of I<all_seed>. Default value is C<123457>.


=item B<all_strength, alls>


=item B<c0_strength, c0s>


=item B<c1_strength, c1s>


=item B<c2_strength, c2s>


=item B<c3_strength, c3s>

Set noise strength for specific pixel component or all pixel components in case
I<all_strength>. Default value is C<0>. Allowed range is [0, 100].


=item B<all_flags, allf>


=item B<c0_flags, c0f>


=item B<c1_flags, c1f>


=item B<c2_flags, c2f>


=item B<c3_flags, c3f>

Set pixel component flags or set flags for all components if I<all_flags>.
Available values for component flags are:

=over 4


=item B<a>

averaged temporal noise (smoother)

=item B<p>

mix random noise with a (semi)regular pattern

=item B<t>

temporal noise (noise pattern changes between frames)

=item B<u>

uniform noise (gaussian otherwise)

=back


=back



=head3 Examples


Add temporal and uniform noise to input video:
	
	noise=alls=20:allf=t+u



=head2 normalize


Normalize RGB video (aka histogram stretching, contrast stretching).
See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normalization_(image_processing)

For each channel of each frame, the filter computes the input range and maps
it linearly to the user-specified output range. The output range defaults
to the full dynamic range from pure black to pure white.

Temporal smoothing can be used on the input range to reduce flickering (rapid
changes in brightness) caused when small dark or bright objects enter or leave
the scene. This is similar to the auto-exposure (automatic gain control) on a
video camera, and, like a video camera, it may cause a period of over- or
under-exposure of the video.

The R,G,B channels can be normalized independently, which may cause some
color shifting, or linked together as a single channel, which prevents
color shifting. Linked normalization preserves hue. Independent normalization
does not, so it can be used to remove some color casts. Independent and linked
normalization can be combined in any ratio.

The normalize filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<blackpt>


=item B<whitept>

Colors which define the output range. The minimum input value is mapped to
the I<blackpt>. The maximum input value is mapped to the I<whitept>.
The defaults are black and white respectively. Specifying white for
I<blackpt> and black for I<whitept> will give color-inverted,
normalized video. Shades of grey can be used to reduce the dynamic range
(contrast). Specifying saturated colors here can create some interesting
effects.


=item B<smoothing>

The number of previous frames to use for temporal smoothing. The input range
of each channel is smoothed using a rolling average over the current frame
and the I<smoothing> previous frames. The default is 0 (no temporal
smoothing).


=item B<independence>

Controls the ratio of independent (color shifting) channel normalization to
linked (color preserving) normalization. 0.0 is fully linked, 1.0 is fully
independent. Defaults to 1.0 (fully independent).


=item B<strength>

Overall strength of the filter. 1.0 is full strength. 0.0 is a rather
expensive no-op. Defaults to 1.0 (full strength).


=back



=head3 Commands

This filter supports same B<commands> as options, excluding I<smoothing> option.
The command accepts the same syntax of the corresponding option.

If the specified expression is not valid, it is kept at its current
value.


=head3 Examples


Stretch video contrast to use the full dynamic range, with no temporal
smoothing; may flicker depending on the source content:
	
	normalize=blackpt=black:whitept=white:smoothing=0


As above, but with 50 frames of temporal smoothing; flicker should be
reduced, depending on the source content:
	
	normalize=blackpt=black:whitept=white:smoothing=50


As above, but with hue-preserving linked channel normalization:
	
	normalize=blackpt=black:whitept=white:smoothing=50:independence=0


As above, but with half strength:
	
	normalize=blackpt=black:whitept=white:smoothing=50:independence=0:strength=0.5


Map the darkest input color to red, the brightest input color to cyan:
	
	normalize=blackpt=red:whitept=cyan



=head2 null


Pass the video source unchanged to the output.


=head2 ocr

Optical Character Recognition

This filter uses Tesseract for optical character recognition. To enable
compilation of this filter, you need to configure FFmpeg with
C<--enable-libtesseract>.

It accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<datapath>

Set datapath to tesseract data. Default is to use whatever was
set at installation.


=item B<language>

Set language, default is "eng".


=item B<whitelist>

Set character whitelist.


=item B<blacklist>

Set character blacklist.

=back


The filter exports recognized text as the frame metadata C<lavfi.ocr.text>.
The filter exports confidence of recognized words as the frame metadata C<lavfi.ocr.confidence>.


=head2 ocv


Apply a video transform using libopencv.

To enable this filter, install the libopencv library and headers and
configure FFmpeg with C<--enable-libopencv>.

It accepts the following parameters:


=over 4



=item B<filter_name>

The name of the libopencv filter to apply.


=item B<filter_params>

The parameters to pass to the libopencv filter. If not specified, the default
values are assumed.


=back


Refer to the official libopencv documentation for more precise
information:
E<lt>B<http://docs.opencv.org/master/modules/imgproc/doc/filtering.html>E<gt>

Several libopencv filters are supported; see the following subsections.



=head3 dilate


Dilate an image by using a specific structuring element.
It corresponds to the libopencv function C<cvDilate>.

It accepts the parameters: I<struct_el>|I<nb_iterations>.

I<struct_el> represents a structuring element, and has the syntax:
I<cols>xI<rows>+I<anchor_x>xI<anchor_y>/I<shape>

I<cols> and I<rows> represent the number of columns and rows of
the structuring element, I<anchor_x> and I<anchor_y> the anchor
point, and I<shape> the shape for the structuring element. I<shape>
must be "rect", "cross", "ellipse", or "custom".

If the value for I<shape> is "custom", it must be followed by a
string of the form "=I<filename>". The file with name
I<filename> is assumed to represent a binary image, with each
printable character corresponding to a bright pixel. When a custom
I<shape> is used, I<cols> and I<rows> are ignored, the number
or columns and rows of the read file are assumed instead.

The default value for I<struct_el> is "3x3+0x0/rect".

I<nb_iterations> specifies the number of times the transform is
applied to the image, and defaults to 1.

Some examples:
	
	# Use the default values
	ocv=dilate
	
	# Dilate using a structuring element with a 5x5 cross, iterating two times
	ocv=filter_name=dilate:filter_params=5x5+2x2/cross|2
	
	# Read the shape from the file diamond.shape, iterating two times.
	# The file diamond.shape may contain a pattern of characters like this
	#   *
	#  ***
	# *****
	#  ***
	#   *
	# The specified columns and rows are ignored
	# but the anchor point coordinates are not
	ocv=dilate:0x0+2x2/custom=diamond.shape|2



=head3 erode


Erode an image by using a specific structuring element.
It corresponds to the libopencv function C<cvErode>.

It accepts the parameters: I<struct_el>:I<nb_iterations>,
with the same syntax and semantics as the B<dilate> filter.


=head3 smooth


Smooth the input video.

The filter takes the following parameters:
I<type>|I<param1>|I<param2>|I<param3>|I<param4>.

I<type> is the type of smooth filter to apply, and must be one of
the following values: "blur", "blur_no_scale", "median", "gaussian",
or "bilateral". The default value is "gaussian".

The meaning of I<param1>, I<param2>, I<param3>, and I<param4>
depends on the smooth type. I<param1> and
I<param2> accept integer positive values or 0. I<param3> and
I<param4> accept floating point values.

The default value for I<param1> is 3. The default value for the
other parameters is 0.

These parameters correspond to the parameters assigned to the
libopencv function C<cvSmooth>.


=head2 oscilloscope


2D Video Oscilloscope.

Useful to measure spatial impulse, step responses, chroma delays, etc.

It accepts the following parameters:


=over 4


=item B<x>

Set scope center x position.


=item B<y>

Set scope center y position.


=item B<s>

Set scope size, relative to frame diagonal.


=item B<t>

Set scope tilt/rotation.


=item B<o>

Set trace opacity.


=item B<tx>

Set trace center x position.


=item B<ty>

Set trace center y position.


=item B<tw>

Set trace width, relative to width of frame.


=item B<th>

Set trace height, relative to height of frame.


=item B<c>

Set which components to trace. By default it traces first three components.


=item B<g>

Draw trace grid. By default is enabled.


=item B<st>

Draw some statistics. By default is enabled.


=item B<sc>

Draw scope. By default is enabled.

=back



=head3 Commands

This filter supports same B<commands> as options.
The command accepts the same syntax of the corresponding option.

If the specified expression is not valid, it is kept at its current
value.


=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Inspect full first row of video frame.
	
	oscilloscope=x=0.5:y=0:s=1



=item *

Inspect full last row of video frame.
	
	oscilloscope=x=0.5:y=1:s=1



=item *

Inspect full 5th line of video frame of height 1080.
	
	oscilloscope=x=0.5:y=5/1080:s=1



=item *

Inspect full last column of video frame.
	
	oscilloscope=x=1:y=0.5:s=1:t=1



=back




=head2 overlay


Overlay one video on top of another.

It takes two inputs and has one output. The first input is the "main"
video on which the second input is overlaid.

It accepts the following parameters:

A description of the accepted options follows.


=over 4


=item B<x>


=item B<y>

Set the expression for the x and y coordinates of the overlaid video
on the main video. Default value is "0" for both expressions. In case
the expression is invalid, it is set to a huge value (meaning that the
overlay will not be displayed within the output visible area).


=item B<eof_action>

See B<framesync>.


=item B<eval>

Set when the expressions for B<x>, and B<y> are evaluated.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<init>

only evaluate expressions once during the filter initialization or
when a command is processed


=item B<frame>

evaluate expressions for each incoming frame

=back


Default value is B<frame>.


=item B<shortest>

See B<framesync>.


=item B<format>

Set the format for the output video.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<yuv420>

force YUV420 output


=item B<yuv420p10>

force YUV420p10 output


=item B<yuv422>

force YUV422 output


=item B<yuv422p10>

force YUV422p10 output


=item B<yuv444>

force YUV444 output


=item B<rgb>

force packed RGB output


=item B<gbrp>

force planar RGB output


=item B<auto>

automatically pick format

=back


Default value is B<yuv420>.


=item B<repeatlast>

See B<framesync>.


=item B<alpha>

Set format of alpha of the overlaid video, it can be I<straight> or
I<premultiplied>. Default is I<straight>.

=back


The B<x>, and B<y> expressions can contain the following
parameters.


=over 4


=item B<main_w, W>


=item B<main_h, H>

The main input width and height.


=item B<overlay_w, w>


=item B<overlay_h, h>

The overlay input width and height.


=item B<x>


=item B<y>

The computed values for I<x> and I<y>. They are evaluated for
each new frame.


=item B<hsub>


=item B<vsub>

horizontal and vertical chroma subsample values of the output
format. For example for the pixel format "yuv422p" I<hsub> is 2 and
I<vsub> is 1.


=item B<n>

the number of input frame, starting from 0


=item B<pos>

the position in the file of the input frame, NAN if unknown


=item B<t>

The timestamp, expressed in seconds. It's NAN if the input timestamp is unknown.


=back


This filter also supports the B<framesync> options.

Note that the I<n>, I<pos>, I<t> variables are available only
when evaluation is done I<per frame>, and will evaluate to NAN
when B<eval> is set to B<init>.

Be aware that frames are taken from each input video in timestamp
order, hence, if their initial timestamps differ, it is a good idea
to pass the two inputs through a I<setpts=PTS-STARTPTS> filter to
have them begin in the same zero timestamp, as the example for
the I<movie> filter does.

You can chain together more overlays but you should test the
efficiency of such approach.


=head3 Commands


This filter supports the following commands:

=over 4


=item B<x>


=item B<y>

Modify the x and y of the overlay input.
The command accepts the same syntax of the corresponding option.

If the specified expression is not valid, it is kept at its current
value.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Draw the overlay at 10 pixels from the bottom right corner of the main
video:
	
	overlay=main_w-overlay_w-10:main_h-overlay_h-10


Using named options the example above becomes:
	
	overlay=x=main_w-overlay_w-10:y=main_h-overlay_h-10



=item *

Insert a transparent PNG logo in the bottom left corner of the input,
using the B<ffmpeg> tool with the C<-filter_complex> option:
	
	ffmpeg -i input -i logo -filter_complex 'overlay=10:main_h-overlay_h-10' output



=item *

Insert 2 different transparent PNG logos (second logo on bottom
right corner) using the B<ffmpeg> tool:
	
	ffmpeg -i input -i logo1 -i logo2 -filter_complex 'overlay=x=10:y=H-h-10,overlay=x=W-w-10:y=H-h-10' output



=item *

Add a transparent color layer on top of the main video; C<WxH>
must specify the size of the main input to the overlay filter:
	
	color=color=red@.3:size=WxH [over]; [in][over] overlay [out]



=item *

Play an original video and a filtered version (here with the deshake
filter) side by side using the B<ffplay> tool:
	
	ffplay input.avi -vf 'split[a][b]; [a]pad=iw*2:ih[src]; [b]deshake[filt]; [src][filt]overlay=w'


The above command is the same as:
	
	ffplay input.avi -vf 'split[b], pad=iw*2[src], [b]deshake, [src]overlay=w'



=item *

Make a sliding overlay appearing from the left to the right top part of the
screen starting since time 2:
	
	overlay=x='if(gte(t,2), -w+(t-2)*20, NAN)':y=0



=item *

Compose output by putting two input videos side to side:
	
	ffmpeg -i left.avi -i right.avi -filter_complex "
	nullsrc=size=200x100 [background];
	[0:v] setpts=PTS-STARTPTS, scale=100x100 [left];
	[1:v] setpts=PTS-STARTPTS, scale=100x100 [right];
	[background][left]       overlay=shortest=1       [background+left];
	[background+left][right] overlay=shortest=1:x=100 [left+right]
	"



=item *

Mask 10-20 seconds of a video by applying the delogo filter to a section
	
	ffmpeg -i test.avi -codec:v:0 wmv2 -ar 11025 -b:v 9000k
	-vf '[in]split[split_main][split_delogo];[split_delogo]trim=start=360:end=371,delogo=0:0:640:480[delogoed];[split_main][delogoed]overlay=eof_action=pass[out]'
	masked.avi



=item *

Chain several overlays in cascade:
	
	nullsrc=s=200x200 [bg];
	testsrc=s=100x100, split=4 [in0][in1][in2][in3];
	[in0] lutrgb=r=0, [bg]   overlay=0:0     [mid0];
	[in1] lutrgb=g=0, [mid0] overlay=100:0   [mid1];
	[in2] lutrgb=b=0, [mid1] overlay=0:100   [mid2];
	[in3] null,       [mid2] overlay=100:100 [out0]



=back




=head2 overlay_cuda


Overlay one video on top of another.

This is the CUDA variant of the B<overlay> filter.
It only accepts CUDA frames. The underlying input pixel formats have to match.

It takes two inputs and has one output. The first input is the "main"
video on which the second input is overlaid.

It accepts the following parameters:


=over 4


=item B<x>


=item B<y>

Set the x and y coordinates of the overlaid video on the main video.
Default value is "0" for both expressions.


=item B<eof_action>

See B<framesync>.


=item B<shortest>

See B<framesync>.


=item B<repeatlast>

See B<framesync>.


=back


This filter also supports the B<framesync> options.


=head2 owdenoise


Apply Overcomplete Wavelet denoiser.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<depth>

Set depth.

Larger depth values will denoise lower frequency components more, but
slow down filtering.

Must be an int in the range 8-16, default is C<8>.


=item B<luma_strength, ls>

Set luma strength.

Must be a double value in the range 0-1000, default is C<1.0>.


=item B<chroma_strength, cs>

Set chroma strength.

Must be a double value in the range 0-1000, default is C<1.0>.

=back




=head2 pad


Add paddings to the input image, and place the original input at the
provided I<x>, I<y> coordinates.

It accepts the following parameters:


=over 4


=item B<width, w>


=item B<height, h>

Specify an expression for the size of the output image with the
paddings added. If the value for I<width> or I<height> is 0, the
corresponding input size is used for the output.

The I<width> expression can reference the value set by the
I<height> expression, and vice versa.

The default value of I<width> and I<height> is 0.


=item B<x>


=item B<y>

Specify the offsets to place the input image at within the padded area,
with respect to the top/left border of the output image.

The I<x> expression can reference the value set by the I<y>
expression, and vice versa.

The default value of I<x> and I<y> is 0.

If I<x> or I<y> evaluate to a negative number, they'll be changed
so the input image is centered on the padded area.


=item B<color>

Specify the color of the padded area. For the syntax of this option,
check the B<"Color" section in the ffmpeg-utils
manual>.

The default value of I<color> is "black".


=item B<eval>

Specify when to evaluate  I<width>, I<height>, I<x> and I<y> expression.

It accepts the following values:


=over 4


=item B<init>

Only evaluate expressions once during the filter initialization or when
a command is processed.


=item B<frame>

Evaluate expressions for each incoming frame.


=back


Default value is B<init>.


=item B<aspect>

Pad to aspect instead to a resolution.


=back


The value for the I<width>, I<height>, I<x>, and I<y>
options are expressions containing the following constants:


=over 4


=item B<in_w>


=item B<in_h>

The input video width and height.


=item B<iw>


=item B<ih>

These are the same as I<in_w> and I<in_h>.


=item B<out_w>


=item B<out_h>

The output width and height (the size of the padded area), as
specified by the I<width> and I<height> expressions.


=item B<ow>


=item B<oh>

These are the same as I<out_w> and I<out_h>.


=item B<x>


=item B<y>

The x and y offsets as specified by the I<x> and I<y>
expressions, or NAN if not yet specified.


=item B<a>

same as I<iw> / I<ih>


=item B<sar>

input sample aspect ratio


=item B<dar>

input display aspect ratio, it is the same as (I<iw> / I<ih>) * I<sar>


=item B<hsub>


=item B<vsub>

The horizontal and vertical chroma subsample values. For example for the
pixel format "yuv422p" I<hsub> is 2 and I<vsub> is 1.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Add paddings with the color "violet" to the input video. The output video
size is 640x480, and the top-left corner of the input video is placed at
column 0, row 40
	
	pad=640:480:0:40:violet


The example above is equivalent to the following command:
	
	pad=width=640:height=480:x=0:y=40:color=violet



=item *

Pad the input to get an output with dimensions increased by 3/2,
and put the input video at the center of the padded area:
	
	pad="3/2*iw:3/2*ih:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2"



=item *

Pad the input to get a squared output with size equal to the maximum
value between the input width and height, and put the input video at
the center of the padded area:
	
	pad="max(iw\,ih):ow:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2"



=item *

Pad the input to get a final w/h ratio of 16:9:
	
	pad="ih*16/9:ih:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2"



=item *

In case of anamorphic video, in order to set the output display aspect
correctly, it is necessary to use I<sar> in the expression,
according to the relation:
	
	(ih * X / ih) * sar = output_dar
	X = output_dar / sar


Thus the previous example needs to be modified to:
	
	pad="ih*16/9/sar:ih:(ow-iw)/2:(oh-ih)/2"



=item *

Double the output size and put the input video in the bottom-right
corner of the output padded area:
	
	pad="2*iw:2*ih:ow-iw:oh-ih"


=back




=head2 palettegen


Generate one palette for a whole video stream.

It accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<max_colors>

Set the maximum number of colors to quantize in the palette.
Note: the palette will still contain 256 colors; the unused palette entries
will be black.


=item B<reserve_transparent>

Create a palette of 255 colors maximum and reserve the last one for
transparency. Reserving the transparency color is useful for GIF optimization.
If not set, the maximum of colors in the palette will be 256. You probably want
to disable this option for a standalone image.
Set by default.


=item B<transparency_color>

Set the color that will be used as background for transparency.


=item B<stats_mode>

Set statistics mode.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<full>

Compute full frame histograms.

=item B<diff>

Compute histograms only for the part that differs from previous frame. This
might be relevant to give more importance to the moving part of your input if
the background is static.

=item B<single>

Compute new histogram for each frame.

=back


Default value is I<full>.

=back


The filter also exports the frame metadata C<lavfi.color_quant_ratio>
(C<nb_color_in / nb_color_out>) which you can use to evaluate the degree of
color quantization of the palette. This information is also visible at
I<info> logging level.


=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Generate a representative palette of a given video using B<ffmpeg>:
	
	ffmpeg -i input.mkv -vf palettegen palette.png


=back



=head2 paletteuse


Use a palette to downsample an input video stream.

The filter takes two inputs: one video stream and a palette. The palette must
be a 256 pixels image.

It accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<dither>

Select dithering mode. Available algorithms are:

=over 4


=item B<bayer>

Ordered 8x8 bayer dithering (deterministic)

=item B<heckbert>

Dithering as defined by Paul Heckbert in 1982 (simple error diffusion).
Note: this dithering is sometimes considered "wrong" and is included as a
reference.

=item B<floyd_steinberg>

Floyd and Steingberg dithering (error diffusion)

=item B<sierra2>

Frankie Sierra dithering v2 (error diffusion)

=item B<sierra2_4a>

Frankie Sierra dithering v2 "Lite" (error diffusion)

=back


Default is I<sierra2_4a>.


=item B<bayer_scale>

When I<bayer> dithering is selected, this option defines the scale of the
pattern (how much the crosshatch pattern is visible). A low value means more
visible pattern for less banding, and higher value means less visible pattern
at the cost of more banding.

The option must be an integer value in the range [0,5]. Default is I<2>.


=item B<diff_mode>

If set, define the zone to process


=over 4


=item B<rectangle>

Only the changing rectangle will be reprocessed. This is similar to GIF
cropping/offsetting compression mechanism. This option can be useful for speed
if only a part of the image is changing, and has use cases such as limiting the
scope of the error diffusal B<dither> to the rectangle that bounds the
moving scene (it leads to more deterministic output if the scene doesn't change
much, and as a result less moving noise and better GIF compression).

=back


Default is I<none>.


=item B<new>

Take new palette for each output frame.


=item B<alpha_threshold>

Sets the alpha threshold for transparency. Alpha values above this threshold
will be treated as completely opaque, and values below this threshold will be
treated as completely transparent.

The option must be an integer value in the range [0,255]. Default is I<128>.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Use a palette (generated for example with B<palettegen>) to encode a GIF
using B<ffmpeg>:
	
	ffmpeg -i input.mkv -i palette.png -lavfi paletteuse output.gif


=back



=head2 perspective


Correct perspective of video not recorded perpendicular to the screen.

A description of the accepted parameters follows.


=over 4


=item B<x0>


=item B<y0>


=item B<x1>


=item B<y1>


=item B<x2>


=item B<y2>


=item B<x3>


=item B<y3>

Set coordinates expression for top left, top right, bottom left and bottom right corners.
Default values are C<0:0:W:0:0:H:W:H> with which perspective will remain unchanged.
If the C<sense> option is set to C<source>, then the specified points will be sent
to the corners of the destination. If the C<sense> option is set to C<destination>,
then the corners of the source will be sent to the specified coordinates.

The expressions can use the following variables:


=over 4


=item B<W>


=item B<H>

the width and height of video frame.

=item B<in>

Input frame count.

=item B<on>

Output frame count.

=back



=item B<interpolation>

Set interpolation for perspective correction.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<linear>


=item B<cubic>


=back


Default value is B<linear>.


=item B<sense>

Set interpretation of coordinate options.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<0, source>


Send point in the source specified by the given coordinates to
the corners of the destination.


=item B<1, destination>


Send the corners of the source to the point in the destination specified
by the given coordinates.

Default value is B<source>.

=back



=item B<eval>

Set when the expressions for coordinates B<x0,y0,...x3,y3> are evaluated.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<init>

only evaluate expressions once during the filter initialization or
when a command is processed


=item B<frame>

evaluate expressions for each incoming frame

=back


Default value is B<init>.

=back



=head2 phase


Delay interlaced video by one field time so that the field order changes.

The intended use is to fix PAL movies that have been captured with the
opposite field order to the film-to-video transfer.

A description of the accepted parameters follows.


=over 4


=item B<mode>

Set phase mode.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<t>

Capture field order top-first, transfer bottom-first.
Filter will delay the bottom field.


=item B<b>

Capture field order bottom-first, transfer top-first.
Filter will delay the top field.


=item B<p>

Capture and transfer with the same field order. This mode only exists
for the documentation of the other options to refer to, but if you
actually select it, the filter will faithfully do nothing.


=item B<a>

Capture field order determined automatically by field flags, transfer
opposite.
Filter selects among B<t> and B<b> modes on a frame by frame
basis using field flags. If no field information is available,
then this works just like B<u>.


=item B<u>

Capture unknown or varying, transfer opposite.
Filter selects among B<t> and B<b> on a frame by frame basis by
analyzing the images and selecting the alternative that produces best
match between the fields.


=item B<T>

Capture top-first, transfer unknown or varying.
Filter selects among B<t> and B<p> using image analysis.


=item B<B>

Capture bottom-first, transfer unknown or varying.
Filter selects among B<b> and B<p> using image analysis.


=item B<A>

Capture determined by field flags, transfer unknown or varying.
Filter selects among B<t>, B<b> and B<p> using field flags and
image analysis. If no field information is available, then this works just
like B<U>. This is the default mode.


=item B<U>

Both capture and transfer unknown or varying.
Filter selects among B<t>, B<b> and B<p> using image analysis only.

=back


=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head2 photosensitivity

Reduce various flashes in video, so to help users with epilepsy.

It accepts the following options:

=over 4


=item B<frames, f>

Set how many frames to use when filtering. Default is 30.


=item B<threshold, t>

Set detection threshold factor. Default is 1.
Lower is stricter.


=item B<skip>

Set how many pixels to skip when sampling frames. Default is 1.
Allowed range is from 1 to 1024.


=item B<bypass>

Leave frames unchanged. Default is disabled.

=back



=head2 pixdesctest


Pixel format descriptor test filter, mainly useful for internal
testing. The output video should be equal to the input video.

For example:
	
	format=monow, pixdesctest


can be used to test the monowhite pixel format descriptor definition.


=head2 pixscope


Display sample values of color channels. Mainly useful for checking color
and levels. Minimum supported resolution is 640x480.

The filters accept the following options:


=over 4


=item B<x>

Set scope X position, relative offset on X axis.


=item B<y>

Set scope Y position, relative offset on Y axis.


=item B<w>

Set scope width.


=item B<h>

Set scope height.


=item B<o>

Set window opacity. This window also holds statistics about pixel area.


=item B<wx>

Set window X position, relative offset on X axis.


=item B<wy>

Set window Y position, relative offset on Y axis.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports same B<commands> as options.


=head2 pp


Enable the specified chain of postprocessing subfilters using libpostproc. This
library should be automatically selected with a GPL build (C<--enable-gpl>).
Subfilters must be separated by '/' and can be disabled by prepending a '-'.
Each subfilter and some options have a short and a long name that can be used
interchangeably, i.e. dr/dering are the same.

The filters accept the following options:


=over 4


=item B<subfilters>

Set postprocessing subfilters string.

=back


All subfilters share common options to determine their scope:


=over 4


=item B<a/autoq>

Honor the quality commands for this subfilter.


=item B<c/chrom>

Do chrominance filtering, too (default).


=item B<y/nochrom>

Do luminance filtering only (no chrominance).


=item B<n/noluma>

Do chrominance filtering only (no luminance).

=back


These options can be appended after the subfilter name, separated by a '|'.

Available subfilters are:


=over 4


=item B<hb/hdeblock[|difference[|flatness]]>

Horizontal deblocking filter

=over 4


=item B<difference>

Difference factor where higher values mean more deblocking (default: C<32>).

=item B<flatness>

Flatness threshold where lower values mean more deblocking (default: C<39>).

=back



=item B<vb/vdeblock[|difference[|flatness]]>

Vertical deblocking filter

=over 4


=item B<difference>

Difference factor where higher values mean more deblocking (default: C<32>).

=item B<flatness>

Flatness threshold where lower values mean more deblocking (default: C<39>).

=back



=item B<ha/hadeblock[|difference[|flatness]]>

Accurate horizontal deblocking filter

=over 4


=item B<difference>

Difference factor where higher values mean more deblocking (default: C<32>).

=item B<flatness>

Flatness threshold where lower values mean more deblocking (default: C<39>).

=back



=item B<va/vadeblock[|difference[|flatness]]>

Accurate vertical deblocking filter

=over 4


=item B<difference>

Difference factor where higher values mean more deblocking (default: C<32>).

=item B<flatness>

Flatness threshold where lower values mean more deblocking (default: C<39>).

=back


=back


The horizontal and vertical deblocking filters share the difference and
flatness values so you cannot set different horizontal and vertical
thresholds.


=over 4


=item B<h1/x1hdeblock>

Experimental horizontal deblocking filter


=item B<v1/x1vdeblock>

Experimental vertical deblocking filter


=item B<dr/dering>

Deringing filter


=item B<tn/tmpnoise[|threshold1[|threshold2[|threshold3]]], temporal noise reducer>


=over 4


=item B<threshold1>

larger -E<gt> stronger filtering

=item B<threshold2>

larger -E<gt> stronger filtering

=item B<threshold3>

larger -E<gt> stronger filtering

=back



=item B<al/autolevels[:f/fullyrange], automatic brightness / contrast correction>


=over 4


=item B<f/fullyrange>

Stretch luminance to C<0-255>.

=back



=item B<lb/linblenddeint>

Linear blend deinterlacing filter that deinterlaces the given block by
filtering all lines with a C<(1 2 1)> filter.


=item B<li/linipoldeint>

Linear interpolating deinterlacing filter that deinterlaces the given block by
linearly interpolating every second line.


=item B<ci/cubicipoldeint>

Cubic interpolating deinterlacing filter deinterlaces the given block by
cubically interpolating every second line.


=item B<md/mediandeint>

Median deinterlacing filter that deinterlaces the given block by applying a
median filter to every second line.


=item B<fd/ffmpegdeint>

FFmpeg deinterlacing filter that deinterlaces the given block by filtering every
second line with a C<(-1 4 2 4 -1)> filter.


=item B<l5/lowpass5>

Vertically applied FIR lowpass deinterlacing filter that deinterlaces the given
block by filtering all lines with a C<(-1 2 6 2 -1)> filter.


=item B<fq/forceQuant[|quantizer]>

Overrides the quantizer table from the input with the constant quantizer you
specify.

=over 4


=item B<quantizer>

Quantizer to use

=back



=item B<de/default>

Default pp filter combination (C<hb|a,vb|a,dr|a>)


=item B<fa/fast>

Fast pp filter combination (C<h1|a,v1|a,dr|a>)


=item B<ac>

High quality pp filter combination (C<ha|a|128|7,va|a,dr|a>)

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Apply horizontal and vertical deblocking, deringing and automatic
brightness/contrast:
	
	pp=hb/vb/dr/al



=item *

Apply default filters without brightness/contrast correction:
	
	pp=de/-al



=item *

Apply default filters and temporal denoiser:
	
	pp=default/tmpnoise|1|2|3



=item *

Apply deblocking on luminance only, and switch vertical deblocking on or off
automatically depending on available CPU time:
	
	pp=hb|y/vb|a


=back



=head2 pp7

Apply Postprocessing filter 7. It is variant of the B<spp> filter,
similar to spp = 6 with 7 point DCT, where only the center sample is
used after IDCT.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<qp>

Force a constant quantization parameter. It accepts an integer in range
0 to 63. If not set, the filter will use the QP from the video stream
(if available).


=item B<mode>

Set thresholding mode. Available modes are:


=over 4


=item B<hard>

Set hard thresholding.

=item B<soft>

Set soft thresholding (better de-ringing effect, but likely blurrier).

=item B<medium>

Set medium thresholding (good results, default).

=back


=back



=head2 premultiply

Apply alpha premultiply effect to input video stream using first plane
of second stream as alpha.

Both streams must have same dimensions and same pixel format.

The filter accepts the following option:


=over 4


=item B<planes>

Set which planes will be processed, unprocessed planes will be copied.
By default value 0xf, all planes will be processed.


=item B<inplace>

Do not require 2nd input for processing, instead use alpha plane from input stream.

=back



=head2 prewitt

Apply prewitt operator to input video stream.

The filter accepts the following option:


=over 4


=item B<planes>

Set which planes will be processed, unprocessed planes will be copied.
By default value 0xf, all planes will be processed.


=item B<scale>

Set value which will be multiplied with filtered result.


=item B<delta>

Set value which will be added to filtered result.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head2 pseudocolor


Alter frame colors in video with pseudocolors.

This filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<c0>

set pixel first component expression


=item B<c1>

set pixel second component expression


=item B<c2>

set pixel third component expression


=item B<c3>

set pixel fourth component expression, corresponds to the alpha component


=item B<index, i>

set component to use as base for altering colors


=item B<preset, p>

Pick one of built-in LUTs. By default is set to none.

Available LUTs:

=over 4


=item B<magma>


=item B<inferno>


=item B<plasma>


=item B<viridis>


=item B<turbo>


=item B<cividis>


=item B<range1>


=item B<range2>


=item B<shadows>


=item B<highlights>


=back



=item B<opacity>

Set opacity of output colors. Allowed range is from 0 to 1.
Default value is set to 1.

=back


Each of the expression options specifies the expression to use for computing
the lookup table for the corresponding pixel component values.

The expressions can contain the following constants and functions:


=over 4


=item B<w>


=item B<h>

The input width and height.


=item B<val>

The input value for the pixel component.


=item B<ymin, umin, vmin, amin>

The minimum allowed component value.


=item B<ymax, umax, vmax, amax>

The maximum allowed component value.

=back


All expressions default to "val".


=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Change too high luma values to gradient:
	
	pseudocolor="'if(between(val,ymax,amax),lerp(ymin,ymax,(val-ymax)/(amax-ymax)),-1):if(between(val,ymax,amax),lerp(umax,umin,(val-ymax)/(amax-ymax)),-1):if(between(val,ymax,amax),lerp(vmin,vmax,(val-ymax)/(amax-ymax)),-1):-1'"


=back



=head2 psnr


Obtain the average, maximum and minimum PSNR (Peak Signal to Noise
Ratio) between two input videos.

This filter takes in input two input videos, the first input is
considered the "main" source and is passed unchanged to the
output. The second input is used as a "reference" video for computing
the PSNR.

Both video inputs must have the same resolution and pixel format for
this filter to work correctly. Also it assumes that both inputs
have the same number of frames, which are compared one by one.

The obtained average PSNR is printed through the logging system.

The filter stores the accumulated MSE (mean squared error) of each
frame, and at the end of the processing it is averaged across all frames
equally, and the following formula is applied to obtain the PSNR:

	
	PSNR = 10*log10(MAX^2/MSE)


Where MAX is the average of the maximum values of each component of the
image.

The description of the accepted parameters follows.


=over 4


=item B<stats_file, f>

If specified the filter will use the named file to save the PSNR of
each individual frame. When filename equals "-" the data is sent to
standard output.


=item B<stats_version>

Specifies which version of the stats file format to use. Details of
each format are written below.
Default value is 1.


=item B<stats_add_max>

Determines whether the max value is output to the stats log.
Default value is 0.
Requires stats_version E<gt>= 2. If this is set and stats_version E<lt> 2,
the filter will return an error.

=back


This filter also supports the B<framesync> options.

The file printed if I<stats_file> is selected, contains a sequence of
key/value pairs of the form I<key>:I<value> for each compared
couple of frames.

If a I<stats_version> greater than 1 is specified, a header line precedes
the list of per-frame-pair stats, with key value pairs following the frame
format with the following parameters:


=over 4


=item B<psnr_log_version>

The version of the log file format. Will match I<stats_version>.


=item B<fields>

A comma separated list of the per-frame-pair parameters included in
the log.

=back


A description of each shown per-frame-pair parameter follows:


=over 4


=item B<n>

sequential number of the input frame, starting from 1


=item B<mse_avg>

Mean Square Error pixel-by-pixel average difference of the compared
frames, averaged over all the image components.


=item B<mse_y, mse_u, mse_v, mse_r, mse_g, mse_b, mse_a>

Mean Square Error pixel-by-pixel average difference of the compared
frames for the component specified by the suffix.


=item B<psnr_y, psnr_u, psnr_v, psnr_r, psnr_g, psnr_b, psnr_a>

Peak Signal to Noise ratio of the compared frames for the component
specified by the suffix.


=item B<max_avg, max_y, max_u, max_v>

Maximum allowed value for each channel, and average over all
channels.

=back



=head3 Examples


=over 4


=item *

For example:
	
	movie=ref_movie.mpg, setpts=PTS-STARTPTS [main];
	[main][ref] psnr="stats_file=stats.log" [out]


On this example the input file being processed is compared with the
reference file F<ref_movie.mpg>. The PSNR of each individual frame
is stored in F<stats.log>.


=item *

Another example with different containers:
