	ffmpeg -i main.mpg -i ref.mkv -lavfi  "[0:v]settb=AVTB,setpts=PTS-STARTPTS[main];[1:v]settb=AVTB,setpts=PTS-STARTPTS[ref];[main][ref]psnr" -f null -


=back




=head2 pullup


Pulldown reversal (inverse telecine) filter, capable of handling mixed
hard-telecine, 24000/1001 fps progressive, and 30000/1001 fps progressive
content.

The pullup filter is designed to take advantage of future context in making
its decisions. This filter is stateless in the sense that it does not lock
onto a pattern to follow, but it instead looks forward to the following
fields in order to identify matches and rebuild progressive frames.

To produce content with an even framerate, insert the fps filter after
pullup, use C<fps=24000/1001> if the input frame rate is 29.97fps,
C<fps=24> for 30fps and the (rare) telecined 25fps input.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<jl>


=item B<jr>


=item B<jt>


=item B<jb>

These options set the amount of "junk" to ignore at the left, right, top, and
bottom of the image, respectively. Left and right are in units of 8 pixels,
while top and bottom are in units of 2 lines.
The default is 8 pixels on each side.


=item B<sb>

Set the strict breaks. Setting this option to 1 will reduce the chances of
filter generating an occasional mismatched frame, but it may also cause an
excessive number of frames to be dropped during high motion sequences.
Conversely, setting it to -1 will make filter match fields more easily.
This may help processing of video where there is slight blurring between
the fields, but may also cause there to be interlaced frames in the output.
Default value is C<0>.


=item B<mp>

Set the metric plane to use. It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<l>

Use luma plane.


=item B<u>

Use chroma blue plane.


=item B<v>

Use chroma red plane.

=back


This option may be set to use chroma plane instead of the default luma plane
for doing filter's computations. This may improve accuracy on very clean
source material, but more likely will decrease accuracy, especially if there
is chroma noise (rainbow effect) or any grayscale video.
The main purpose of setting B<mp> to a chroma plane is to reduce CPU
load and make pullup usable in realtime on slow machines.

=back


For best results (without duplicated frames in the output file) it is
necessary to change the output frame rate. For example, to inverse
telecine NTSC input:
	
	ffmpeg -i input -vf pullup -r 24000/1001 ...



=head2 qp


Change video quantization parameters (QP).

The filter accepts the following option:


=over 4


=item B<qp>

Set expression for quantization parameter.

=back


The expression is evaluated through the eval API and can contain, among others,
the following constants:


=over 4


=item I<known>

1 if index is not 129, 0 otherwise.


=item I<qp>

Sequential index starting from -129 to 128.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Some equation like:
	
	qp=2+2*sin(PI*qp)


=back



=head2 random


Flush video frames from internal cache of frames into a random order.
No frame is discarded.
Inspired by B<frei0r> nervous filter.


=over 4


=item B<frames>

Set size in number of frames of internal cache, in range from C<2> to
C<512>. Default is C<30>.


=item B<seed>

Set seed for random number generator, must be an integer included between
C<0> and C<UINT32_MAX>. If not specified, or if explicitly set to
less than C<0>, the filter will try to use a good random seed on a
best effort basis.

=back



=head2 readeia608


Read closed captioning (EIA-608) information from the top lines of a video frame.

This filter adds frame metadata for C<lavfi.readeia608.X.cc> and
C<lavfi.readeia608.X.line>, where C<X> is the number of the identified line
with EIA-608 data (starting from 0). A description of each metadata value follows:


=over 4


=item B<lavfi.readeia608.X.cc>

The two bytes stored as EIA-608 data (printed in hexadecimal).


=item B<lavfi.readeia608.X.line>

The number of the line on which the EIA-608 data was identified and read.

=back


This filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<scan_min>

Set the line to start scanning for EIA-608 data. Default is C<0>.


=item B<scan_max>

Set the line to end scanning for EIA-608 data. Default is C<29>.


=item B<spw>

Set the ratio of width reserved for sync code detection.
Default is C<0.27>. Allowed range is C<[0.1 - 0.7]>.


=item B<chp>

Enable checking the parity bit. In the event of a parity error, the filter will output
C<0x00> for that character. Default is false.


=item B<lp>

Lowpass lines prior to further processing. Default is enabled.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Output a csv with presentation time and the first two lines of identified EIA-608 captioning data.
	
	ffprobe -f lavfi -i movie=captioned_video.mov,readeia608 -show_entries frame=pkt_pts_time:frame_tags=lavfi.readeia608.0.cc,lavfi.readeia608.1.cc -of csv


=back



=head2 readvitc


Read vertical interval timecode (VITC) information from the top lines of a
video frame.

The filter adds frame metadata key C<lavfi.readvitc.tc_str> with the
timecode value, if a valid timecode has been detected. Further metadata key
C<lavfi.readvitc.found> is set to 0/1 depending on whether
timecode data has been found or not.

This filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<scan_max>

Set the maximum number of lines to scan for VITC data. If the value is set to
C<-1> the full video frame is scanned. Default is C<45>.


=item B<thr_b>

Set the luma threshold for black. Accepts float numbers in the range [0.0,1.0],
default value is C<0.2>. The value must be equal or less than C<thr_w>.


=item B<thr_w>

Set the luma threshold for white. Accepts float numbers in the range [0.0,1.0],
default value is C<0.6>. The value must be equal or greater than C<thr_b>.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Detect and draw VITC data onto the video frame; if no valid VITC is detected,
draw C<--:--:--:--> as a placeholder:
	
	ffmpeg -i input.avi -filter:v 'readvitc,drawtext=fontfile=FreeMono.ttf:text=%{metadata\\:lavfi.readvitc.tc_str\\:--\\\\\\:--\\\\\\:--\\\\\\:--}:x=(w-tw)/2:y=400-ascent'


=back



=head2 remap


Remap pixels using 2nd: Xmap and 3rd: Ymap input video stream.

Destination pixel at position (X, Y) will be picked from source (x, y) position
where x = Xmap(X, Y) and y = Ymap(X, Y). If mapping values are out of range, zero
value for pixel will be used for destination pixel.

Xmap and Ymap input video streams must be of same dimensions. Output video stream
will have Xmap/Ymap video stream dimensions.
Xmap and Ymap input video streams are 16bit depth, single channel.


=over 4


=item B<format>

Specify pixel format of output from this filter. Can be C<color> or C<gray>.
Default is C<color>.


=item B<fill>

Specify the color of the unmapped pixels. For the syntax of this option,
check the B<"Color" section in the ffmpeg-utils
manual>. Default color is C<black>.

=back



=head2 removegrain


The removegrain filter is a spatial denoiser for progressive video.


=over 4


=item B<m0>

Set mode for the first plane.


=item B<m1>

Set mode for the second plane.


=item B<m2>

Set mode for the third plane.


=item B<m3>

Set mode for the fourth plane.

=back


Range of mode is from 0 to 24. Description of each mode follows:


=over 4


=item I<0>

Leave input plane unchanged. Default.


=item I<1>

Clips the pixel with the minimum and maximum of the 8 neighbour pixels.


=item I<2>

Clips the pixel with the second minimum and maximum of the 8 neighbour pixels.


=item I<3>

Clips the pixel with the third minimum and maximum of the 8 neighbour pixels.


=item I<4>

Clips the pixel with the fourth minimum and maximum of the 8 neighbour pixels.
This is equivalent to a median filter.


=item I<5>

Line-sensitive clipping giving the minimal change.


=item I<6>

Line-sensitive clipping, intermediate.


=item I<7>

Line-sensitive clipping, intermediate.


=item I<8>

Line-sensitive clipping, intermediate.


=item I<9>

Line-sensitive clipping on a line where the neighbours pixels are the closest.


=item I<10>

Replaces the target pixel with the closest neighbour.


=item I<11>

[1 2 1] horizontal and vertical kernel blur.


=item I<12>

Same as mode 11.


=item I<13>

Bob mode, interpolates top field from the line where the neighbours
pixels are the closest.


=item I<14>

Bob mode, interpolates bottom field from the line where the neighbours
pixels are the closest.


=item I<15>

Bob mode, interpolates top field. Same as 13 but with a more complicated
interpolation formula.


=item I<16>

Bob mode, interpolates bottom field. Same as 14 but with a more complicated
interpolation formula.


=item I<17>

Clips the pixel with the minimum and maximum of respectively the maximum and
minimum of each pair of opposite neighbour pixels.


=item I<18>

Line-sensitive clipping using opposite neighbours whose greatest distance from
the current pixel is minimal.


=item I<19>

Replaces the pixel with the average of its 8 neighbours.


=item I<20>

Averages the 9 pixels ([1 1 1] horizontal and vertical blur).


=item I<21>

Clips pixels using the averages of opposite neighbour.


=item I<22>

Same as mode 21 but simpler and faster.


=item I<23>

Small edge and halo removal, but reputed useless.


=item I<24>

Similar as 23.

=back



=head2 removelogo


Suppress a TV station logo, using an image file to determine which
pixels comprise the logo. It works by filling in the pixels that
comprise the logo with neighboring pixels.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<filename, f>

Set the filter bitmap file, which can be any image format supported by
libavformat. The width and height of the image file must match those of the
video stream being processed.

=back


Pixels in the provided bitmap image with a value of zero are not
considered part of the logo, non-zero pixels are considered part of
the logo. If you use white (255) for the logo and black (0) for the
rest, you will be safe. For making the filter bitmap, it is
recommended to take a screen capture of a black frame with the logo
visible, and then using a threshold filter followed by the erode
filter once or twice.

If needed, little splotches can be fixed manually. Remember that if
logo pixels are not covered, the filter quality will be much
reduced. Marking too many pixels as part of the logo does not hurt as
much, but it will increase the amount of blurring needed to cover over
the image and will destroy more information than necessary, and extra
pixels will slow things down on a large logo.


=head2 repeatfields


This filter uses the repeat_field flag from the Video ES headers and hard repeats
fields based on its value.


=head2 reverse


Reverse a video clip.

Warning: This filter requires memory to buffer the entire clip, so trimming
is suggested.


=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Take the first 5 seconds of a clip, and reverse it.
	
	trim=end=5,reverse


=back



=head2 rgbashift

Shift R/G/B/A pixels horizontally and/or vertically.

The filter accepts the following options:

=over 4


=item B<rh>

Set amount to shift red horizontally.

=item B<rv>

Set amount to shift red vertically.

=item B<gh>

Set amount to shift green horizontally.

=item B<gv>

Set amount to shift green vertically.

=item B<bh>

Set amount to shift blue horizontally.

=item B<bv>

Set amount to shift blue vertically.

=item B<ah>

Set amount to shift alpha horizontally.

=item B<av>

Set amount to shift alpha vertically.

=item B<edge>

Set edge mode, can be I<smear>, default, or I<warp>.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head2 roberts

Apply roberts cross operator to input video stream.

The filter accepts the following option:


=over 4


=item B<planes>

Set which planes will be processed, unprocessed planes will be copied.
By default value 0xf, all planes will be processed.


=item B<scale>

Set value which will be multiplied with filtered result.


=item B<delta>

Set value which will be added to filtered result.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head2 rotate


Rotate video by an arbitrary angle expressed in radians.

The filter accepts the following options:

A description of the optional parameters follows.

=over 4


=item B<angle, a>

Set an expression for the angle by which to rotate the input video
clockwise, expressed as a number of radians. A negative value will
result in a counter-clockwise rotation. By default it is set to "0".

This expression is evaluated for each frame.


=item B<out_w, ow>

Set the output width expression, default value is "iw".
This expression is evaluated just once during configuration.


=item B<out_h, oh>

Set the output height expression, default value is "ih".
This expression is evaluated just once during configuration.


=item B<bilinear>

Enable bilinear interpolation if set to 1, a value of 0 disables
it. Default value is 1.


=item B<fillcolor, c>

Set the color used to fill the output area not covered by the rotated
image. For the general syntax of this option, check the
B<"Color" section in the ffmpeg-utils manual>.
If the special value "none" is selected then no
background is printed (useful for example if the background is never shown).

Default value is "black".

=back


The expressions for the angle and the output size can contain the
following constants and functions:


=over 4


=item B<n>

sequential number of the input frame, starting from 0. It is always NAN
before the first frame is filtered.


=item B<t>

time in seconds of the input frame, it is set to 0 when the filter is
configured. It is always NAN before the first frame is filtered.


=item B<hsub>


=item B<vsub>

horizontal and vertical chroma subsample values. For example for the
pixel format "yuv422p" I<hsub> is 2 and I<vsub> is 1.


=item B<in_w, iw>


=item B<in_h, ih>

the input video width and height


=item B<out_w, ow>


=item B<out_h, oh>

the output width and height, that is the size of the padded area as
specified by the I<width> and I<height> expressions


=item B<rotw(a)>


=item B<roth(a)>

the minimal width/height required for completely containing the input
video rotated by I<a> radians.

These are only available when computing the B<out_w> and
B<out_h> expressions.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Rotate the input by PI/6 radians clockwise:
	
	rotate=PI/6



=item *

Rotate the input by PI/6 radians counter-clockwise:
	
	rotate=-PI/6



=item *

Rotate the input by 45 degrees clockwise:
	
	rotate=45*PI/180



=item *

Apply a constant rotation with period T, starting from an angle of PI/3:
	
	rotate=PI/3+2*PI*t/T



=item *

Make the input video rotation oscillating with a period of T
seconds and an amplitude of A radians:
	
	rotate=A*sin(2*PI/T*t)



=item *

Rotate the video, output size is chosen so that the whole rotating
input video is always completely contained in the output:
	
	rotate='2*PI*t:ow=hypot(iw,ih):oh=ow'



=item *

Rotate the video, reduce the output size so that no background is ever
shown:
	
	rotate=2*PI*t:ow='min(iw,ih)/sqrt(2)':oh=ow:c=none


=back



=head3 Commands


The filter supports the following commands:


=over 4


=item B<a, angle>

Set the angle expression.
The command accepts the same syntax of the corresponding option.

If the specified expression is not valid, it is kept at its current
value.

=back



=head2 sab


Apply Shape Adaptive Blur.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<luma_radius, lr>

Set luma blur filter strength, must be a value in range 0.1-4.0, default
value is 1.0. A greater value will result in a more blurred image, and
in slower processing.


=item B<luma_pre_filter_radius, lpfr>

Set luma pre-filter radius, must be a value in the 0.1-2.0 range, default
value is 1.0.


=item B<luma_strength, ls>

Set luma maximum difference between pixels to still be considered, must
be a value in the 0.1-100.0 range, default value is 1.0.


=item B<chroma_radius, cr>

Set chroma blur filter strength, must be a value in range -0.9-4.0. A
greater value will result in a more blurred image, and in slower
processing.


=item B<chroma_pre_filter_radius, cpfr>

Set chroma pre-filter radius, must be a value in the -0.9-2.0 range.


=item B<chroma_strength, cs>

Set chroma maximum difference between pixels to still be considered,
must be a value in the -0.9-100.0 range.

=back


Each chroma option value, if not explicitly specified, is set to the
corresponding luma option value.



=head2 scale


Scale (resize) the input video, using the libswscale library.

The scale filter forces the output display aspect ratio to be the same
of the input, by changing the output sample aspect ratio.

If the input image format is different from the format requested by
the next filter, the scale filter will convert the input to the
requested format.


=head3 Options

The filter accepts the following options, or any of the options
supported by the libswscale scaler.

See B<the ffmpeg-scaler manual> for
the complete list of scaler options.


=over 4


=item B<width, w>


=item B<height, h>

Set the output video dimension expression. Default value is the input
dimension.

If the I<width> or I<w> value is 0, the input width is used for
the output. If the I<height> or I<h> value is 0, the input height
is used for the output.

If one and only one of the values is -n with n E<gt>= 1, the scale filter
will use a value that maintains the aspect ratio of the input image,
calculated from the other specified dimension. After that it will,
however, make sure that the calculated dimension is divisible by n and
adjust the value if necessary.

If both values are -n with n E<gt>= 1, the behavior will be identical to
both values being set to 0 as previously detailed.

See below for the list of accepted constants for use in the dimension
expression.


=item B<eval>

Specify when to evaluate I<width> and I<height> expression. It accepts the following values:


=over 4


=item B<init>

Only evaluate expressions once during the filter initialization or when a command is processed.


=item B<frame>

Evaluate expressions for each incoming frame.


=back


Default value is B<init>.



=item B<interl>

Set the interlacing mode. It accepts the following values:


=over 4


=item B<1>

Force interlaced aware scaling.


=item B<0>

Do not apply interlaced scaling.


=item B<-1>

Select interlaced aware scaling depending on whether the source frames
are flagged as interlaced or not.

=back


Default value is B<0>.


=item B<flags>

Set libswscale scaling flags. See
B<the ffmpeg-scaler manual> for the
complete list of values. If not explicitly specified the filter applies
the default flags.



=item B<param0, param1>

Set libswscale input parameters for scaling algorithms that need them. See
B<the ffmpeg-scaler manual> for the
complete documentation. If not explicitly specified the filter applies
empty parameters.




=item B<size, s>

Set the video size. For the syntax of this option, check the
B<"Video size" section in the ffmpeg-utils manual>.


=item B<in_color_matrix>


=item B<out_color_matrix>

Set in/output YCbCr color space type.

This allows the autodetected value to be overridden as well as allows forcing
a specific value used for the output and encoder.

If not specified, the color space type depends on the pixel format.

Possible values:


=over 4


=item B<auto>

Choose automatically.


=item B<bt709>

Format conforming to International Telecommunication Union (ITU)
Recommendation BT.709.


=item B<fcc>

Set color space conforming to the United States Federal Communications
Commission (FCC) Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Title 47 (2003) 73.682 (a).


=item B<bt601>


=item B<bt470>


=item B<smpte170m>

Set color space conforming to:


=over 4


=item *

ITU Radiocommunication Sector (ITU-R) Recommendation BT.601


=item *

ITU-R Rec. BT.470-6 (1998) Systems B, B1, and G


=item *

Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers (SMPTE) ST 170:2004


=back



=item B<smpte240m>

Set color space conforming to SMPTE ST 240:1999.


=item B<bt2020>

Set color space conforming to ITU-R BT.2020 non-constant luminance system.

=back



=item B<in_range>


=item B<out_range>

Set in/output YCbCr sample range.

This allows the autodetected value to be overridden as well as allows forcing
a specific value used for the output and encoder. If not specified, the
range depends on the pixel format. Possible values:


=over 4


=item B<auto/unknown>

Choose automatically.


=item B<jpeg/full/pc>

Set full range (0-255 in case of 8-bit luma).


=item B<mpeg/limited/tv>

Set "MPEG" range (16-235 in case of 8-bit luma).

=back



=item B<force_original_aspect_ratio>

Enable decreasing or increasing output video width or height if necessary to
keep the original aspect ratio. Possible values:


=over 4


=item B<disable>

Scale the video as specified and disable this feature.


=item B<decrease>

The output video dimensions will automatically be decreased if needed.


=item B<increase>

The output video dimensions will automatically be increased if needed.


=back


One useful instance of this option is that when you know a specific device's
maximum allowed resolution, you can use this to limit the output video to
that, while retaining the aspect ratio. For example, device A allows
1280x720 playback, and your video is 1920x800. Using this option (set it to
decrease) and specifying 1280x720 to the command line makes the output
1280x533.

Please note that this is a different thing than specifying -1 for B<w>
or B<h>, you still need to specify the output resolution for this option
to work.


=item B<force_divisible_by>

Ensures that both the output dimensions, width and height, are divisible by the
given integer when used together with B<force_original_aspect_ratio>. This
works similar to using C<-n> in the B<w> and B<h> options.

This option respects the value set for B<force_original_aspect_ratio>,
increasing or decreasing the resolution accordingly. The video's aspect ratio
may be slightly modified.

This option can be handy if you need to have a video fit within or exceed
a defined resolution using B<force_original_aspect_ratio> but also have
encoder restrictions on width or height divisibility.


=back


The values of the B<w> and B<h> options are expressions
containing the following constants:


=over 4


=item I<in_w>


=item I<in_h>

The input width and height


=item I<iw>


=item I<ih>

These are the same as I<in_w> and I<in_h>.


=item I<out_w>


=item I<out_h>

The output (scaled) width and height


=item I<ow>


=item I<oh>

These are the same as I<out_w> and I<out_h>


=item I<a>

The same as I<iw> / I<ih>


=item I<sar>

input sample aspect ratio


=item I<dar>

The input display aspect ratio. Calculated from C<(iw / ih) * sar>.


=item I<hsub>


=item I<vsub>

horizontal and vertical input chroma subsample values. For example for the
pixel format "yuv422p" I<hsub> is 2 and I<vsub> is 1.


=item I<ohsub>


=item I<ovsub>

horizontal and vertical output chroma subsample values. For example for the
pixel format "yuv422p" I<hsub> is 2 and I<vsub> is 1.


=item I<n>

The (sequential) number of the input frame, starting from 0.
Only available with C<eval=frame>.


=item I<t>

The presentation timestamp of the input frame, expressed as a number of
seconds. Only available with C<eval=frame>.


=item I<pos>

The position (byte offset) of the frame in the input stream, or NaN if
this information is unavailable and/or meaningless (for example in case of synthetic video).
Only available with C<eval=frame>.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Scale the input video to a size of 200x100
	
	scale=w=200:h=100


This is equivalent to:
	
	scale=200:100


or:
	
	scale=200x100



=item *

Specify a size abbreviation for the output size:
	
	scale=qcif


which can also be written as:
	
	scale=size=qcif



=item *

Scale the input to 2x:
	
	scale=w=2*iw:h=2*ih



=item *

The above is the same as:
	
	scale=2*in_w:2*in_h



=item *

Scale the input to 2x with forced interlaced scaling:
	
	scale=2*iw:2*ih:interl=1



=item *

Scale the input to half size:
	
	scale=w=iw/2:h=ih/2



=item *

Increase the width, and set the height to the same size:
	
	scale=3/2*iw:ow



=item *

Seek Greek harmony:
	
	scale=iw:1/PHI*iw
	scale=ih*PHI:ih



=item *

Increase the height, and set the width to 3/2 of the height:
	
	scale=w=3/2*oh:h=3/5*ih



=item *

Increase the size, making the size a multiple of the chroma
subsample values:
	
	scale="trunc(3/2*iw/hsub)*hsub:trunc(3/2*ih/vsub)*vsub"



=item *

Increase the width to a maximum of 500 pixels,
keeping the same aspect ratio as the input:
	
	scale=w='min(500\, iw*3/2):h=-1'



=item *

Make pixels square by combining scale and setsar:
	
	scale='trunc(ih*dar):ih',setsar=1/1



=item *

Make pixels square by combining scale and setsar,
making sure the resulting resolution is even (required by some codecs):
	
	scale='trunc(ih*dar/2)*2:trunc(ih/2)*2',setsar=1/1


=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the following commands:

=over 4


=item B<width, w>


=item B<height, h>

Set the output video dimension expression.
The command accepts the same syntax of the corresponding option.

If the specified expression is not valid, it is kept at its current
value.

=back



=head2 scale_npp


Use the NVIDIA Performance Primitives (libnpp) to perform scaling and/or pixel
format conversion on CUDA video frames. Setting the output width and height
works in the same way as for the I<scale> filter.

The following additional options are accepted:

=over 4


=item B<format>

The pixel format of the output CUDA frames. If set to the string "same" (the
default), the input format will be kept. Note that automatic format negotiation
and conversion is not yet supported for hardware frames


=item B<interp_algo>

The interpolation algorithm used for resizing. One of the following:

=over 4


=item B<nn>

Nearest neighbour.


=item B<linear>


=item B<cubic>


=item B<cubic2p_bspline>

2-parameter cubic (B=1, C=0)


=item B<cubic2p_catmullrom>

2-parameter cubic (B=0, C=1/2)


=item B<cubic2p_b05c03>

2-parameter cubic (B=1/2, C=3/10)


=item B<super>

Supersampling


=item B<lanczos>


=back



=item B<force_original_aspect_ratio>

Enable decreasing or increasing output video width or height if necessary to
keep the original aspect ratio. Possible values:


=over 4


=item B<disable>

Scale the video as specified and disable this feature.


=item B<decrease>

The output video dimensions will automatically be decreased if needed.


=item B<increase>

The output video dimensions will automatically be increased if needed.


=back


One useful instance of this option is that when you know a specific device's
maximum allowed resolution, you can use this to limit the output video to
that, while retaining the aspect ratio. For example, device A allows
1280x720 playback, and your video is 1920x800. Using this option (set it to
decrease) and specifying 1280x720 to the command line makes the output
1280x533.

Please note that this is a different thing than specifying -1 for B<w>
or B<h>, you still need to specify the output resolution for this option
to work.


=item B<force_divisible_by>

Ensures that both the output dimensions, width and height, are divisible by the
given integer when used together with B<force_original_aspect_ratio>. This
works similar to using C<-n> in the B<w> and B<h> options.

This option respects the value set for B<force_original_aspect_ratio>,
increasing or decreasing the resolution accordingly. The video's aspect ratio
may be slightly modified.

This option can be handy if you need to have a video fit within or exceed
a defined resolution using B<force_original_aspect_ratio> but also have
encoder restrictions on width or height divisibility.


=back



=head2 scale2ref


Scale (resize) the input video, based on a reference video.

See the scale filter for available options, scale2ref supports the same but
uses the reference video instead of the main input as basis. scale2ref also
supports the following additional constants for the B<w> and
B<h> options:


=over 4


=item I<main_w>


=item I<main_h>

The main input video's width and height


=item I<main_a>

The same as I<main_w> / I<main_h>


=item I<main_sar>

The main input video's sample aspect ratio


=item I<main_dar, mdar>

The main input video's display aspect ratio. Calculated from
C<(main_w / main_h) * main_sar>.


=item I<main_hsub>


=item I<main_vsub>

The main input video's horizontal and vertical chroma subsample values.
For example for the pixel format "yuv422p" I<hsub> is 2 and I<vsub>
is 1.


=item I<main_n>

The (sequential) number of the main input frame, starting from 0.
Only available with C<eval=frame>.


=item I<main_t>

The presentation timestamp of the main input frame, expressed as a number of
seconds. Only available with C<eval=frame>.


=item I<main_pos>

The position (byte offset) of the frame in the main input stream, or NaN if
this information is unavailable and/or meaningless (for example in case of synthetic video).
Only available with C<eval=frame>.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Scale a subtitle stream (b) to match the main video (a) in size before overlaying
	
	'scale2ref[b][a];[a][b]overlay'



=item *

Scale a logo to 1/10th the height of a video, while preserving its display aspect ratio.
	
	[logo-in][video-in]scale2ref=w=oh*mdar:h=ih/10[logo-out][video-out]


=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the following commands:

=over 4


=item B<width, w>


=item B<height, h>

Set the output video dimension expression.
The command accepts the same syntax of the corresponding option.

If the specified expression is not valid, it is kept at its current
value.

=back



=head2 scroll

Scroll input video horizontally and/or vertically by constant speed.

The filter accepts the following options:

=over 4


=item B<horizontal, h>

Set the horizontal scrolling speed. Default is 0. Allowed range is from -1 to 1.
Negative values changes scrolling direction.


=item B<vertical, v>

Set the vertical scrolling speed. Default is 0. Allowed range is from -1 to 1.
Negative values changes scrolling direction.


=item B<hpos>

Set the initial horizontal scrolling position. Default is 0. Allowed range is from 0 to 1.


=item B<vpos>

Set the initial vertical scrolling position. Default is 0. Allowed range is from 0 to 1.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the following B<commands>:

=over 4


=item B<horizontal, h>

Set the horizontal scrolling speed.

=item B<vertical, v>

Set the vertical scrolling speed.

=back




=head2 scdet


Detect video scene change.

This filter sets frame metadata with mafd between frame, the scene score, and
forward the frame to the next filter, so they can use these metadata to detect
scene change or others.

In addition, this filter logs a message and sets frame metadata when it detects
a scene change by B<threshold>.

C<lavfi.scd.mafd> metadata keys are set with mafd for every frame.

C<lavfi.scd.score> metadata keys are set with scene change score for every frame
to detect scene change.

C<lavfi.scd.time> metadata keys are set with current filtered frame time which
detect scene change with B<threshold>.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<threshold, t>

Set the scene change detection threshold as a percentage of maximum change. Good
values are in the C<[8.0, 14.0]> range. The range for B<threshold> is
C<[0., 100.]>.

Default value is C<10.>.


=item B<sc_pass, s>

Set the flag to pass scene change frames to the next filter. Default value is C<0>
You can enable it if you want to get snapshot of scene change frames only.

=back




=head2 selectivecolor


Adjust cyan, magenta, yellow and black (CMYK) to certain ranges of colors (such
as "reds", "yellows", "greens", "cyans", ...). The adjustment range is defined
by the "purity" of the color (that is, how saturated it already is).

This filter is similar to the Adobe Photoshop Selective Color tool.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<correction_method>

Select color correction method.

Available values are:

=over 4


=item B<absolute>

Specified adjustments are applied "as-is" (added/subtracted to original pixel
component value).

=item B<relative>

Specified adjustments are relative to the original component value.

=back

Default is C<absolute>.

=item B<reds>

Adjustments for red pixels (pixels where the red component is the maximum)

=item B<yellows>

Adjustments for yellow pixels (pixels where the blue component is the minimum)

=item B<greens>

Adjustments for green pixels (pixels where the green component is the maximum)

=item B<cyans>

Adjustments for cyan pixels (pixels where the red component is the minimum)

=item B<blues>

Adjustments for blue pixels (pixels where the blue component is the maximum)

=item B<magentas>

Adjustments for magenta pixels (pixels where the green component is the minimum)

=item B<whites>

Adjustments for white pixels (pixels where all components are greater than 128)

=item B<neutrals>

Adjustments for all pixels except pure black and pure white

=item B<blacks>

Adjustments for black pixels (pixels where all components are lesser than 128)

=item B<psfile>

Specify a Photoshop selective color file (C<.asv>) to import the settings from.

=back


All the adjustment settings (B<reds>, B<yellows>, ...) accept up to
4 space separated floating point adjustment values in the [-1,1] range,
respectively to adjust the amount of cyan, magenta, yellow and black for the
pixels of its range.


=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Increase cyan by 50% and reduce yellow by 33% in every green areas, and
increase magenta by 27% in blue areas:
	
	selectivecolor=greens=.5 0 -.33 0:blues=0 .27



=item *

Use a Photoshop selective color preset:
	
	selectivecolor=psfile=MySelectiveColorPresets/Misty.asv


=back




=head2 separatefields


The C<separatefields> takes a frame-based video input and splits
each frame into its components fields, producing a new half height clip
with twice the frame rate and twice the frame count.

This filter use field-dominance information in frame to decide which
of each pair of fields to place first in the output.
If it gets it wrong use B<setfield> filter before C<separatefields> filter.


=head2 setdar, setsar


The C<setdar> filter sets the Display Aspect Ratio for the filter
output video.

This is done by changing the specified Sample (aka Pixel) Aspect
Ratio, according to the following equation:
	
	<DAR> = <HORIZONTAL_RESOLUTION> / <VERTICAL_RESOLUTION> * <SAR>


Keep in mind that the C<setdar> filter does not modify the pixel
dimensions of the video frame. Also, the display aspect ratio set by
this filter may be changed by later filters in the filterchain,
e.g. in case of scaling or if another "setdar" or a "setsar" filter is
applied.

The C<setsar> filter sets the Sample (aka Pixel) Aspect Ratio for
the filter output video.

Note that as a consequence of the application of this filter, the
output display aspect ratio will change according to the equation
above.

Keep in mind that the sample aspect ratio set by the C<setsar>
filter may be changed by later filters in the filterchain, e.g. if
another "setsar" or a "setdar" filter is applied.

It accepts the following parameters:


=over 4


=item B<r, ratio, dar (C<setdar> only), sar (C<setsar> only)>

Set the aspect ratio used by the filter.

The parameter can be a floating point number string, an expression, or
a string of the form I<num>:I<den>, where I<num> and
I<den> are the numerator and denominator of the aspect ratio. If
the parameter is not specified, it is assumed the value "0".
In case the form "I<num>:I<den>" is used, the C<:> character
should be escaped.


=item B<max>

Set the maximum integer value to use for expressing numerator and
denominator when reducing the expressed aspect ratio to a rational.
Default value is C<100>.


=back


The parameter I<sar> is an expression containing
the following constants:


=over 4


=item B<E, PI, PHI>

These are approximated values for the mathematical constants e
(Euler's number), pi (Greek pi), and phi (the golden ratio).


=item B<w, h>

The input width and height.


=item B<a>

These are the same as I<w> / I<h>.


=item B<sar>

The input sample aspect ratio.


=item B<dar>

The input display aspect ratio. It is the same as
(I<w> / I<h>) * I<sar>.


=item B<hsub, vsub>

Horizontal and vertical chroma subsample values. For example, for the
pixel format "yuv422p" I<hsub> is 2 and I<vsub> is 1.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4



=item *

To change the display aspect ratio to 16:9, specify one of the following:
	
	setdar=dar=1.77777
	setdar=dar=16/9



=item *

To change the sample aspect ratio to 10:11, specify:
	
	setsar=sar=10/11



=item *

To set a display aspect ratio of 16:9, and specify a maximum integer value of
1000 in the aspect ratio reduction, use the command:
	
	setdar=ratio=16/9:max=1000



=back




=head2 setfield


Force field for the output video frame.

The C<setfield> filter marks the interlace type field for the
output frames. It does not change the input frame, but only sets the
corresponding property, which affects how the frame is treated by
following filters (e.g. C<fieldorder> or C<yadif>).

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4



=item B<mode>

Available values are:


=over 4


=item B<auto>

Keep the same field property.


=item B<bff>

Mark the frame as bottom-field-first.


=item B<tff>

Mark the frame as top-field-first.


=item B<prog>

Mark the frame as progressive.

=back


=back




=head2 setparams


Force frame parameter for the output video frame.

The C<setparams> filter marks interlace and color range for the
output frames. It does not change the input frame, but only sets the
corresponding property, which affects how the frame is treated by
filters/encoders.


=over 4


=item B<field_mode>

Available values are:


=over 4


=item B<auto>

Keep the same field property (default).


=item B<bff>

Mark the frame as bottom-field-first.


=item B<tff>

Mark the frame as top-field-first.


=item B<prog>

Mark the frame as progressive.

=back



=item B<range>

Available values are:


=over 4


=item B<auto>

Keep the same color range property (default).


=item B<unspecified, unknown>

Mark the frame as unspecified color range.


=item B<limited, tv, mpeg>

Mark the frame as limited range.


=item B<full, pc, jpeg>

Mark the frame as full range.

=back



=item B<color_primaries>

Set the color primaries.
Available values are:


=over 4


=item B<auto>

Keep the same color primaries property (default).


=item B<bt709>


=item B<unknown>


=item B<bt470m>


=item B<bt470bg>


=item B<smpte170m>


=item B<smpte240m>


=item B<film>


=item B<bt2020>


=item B<smpte428>


=item B<smpte431>


=item B<smpte432>


=item B<jedec-p22>


=back



=item B<color_trc>

Set the color transfer.
Available values are:


=over 4


=item B<auto>

Keep the same color trc property (default).


=item B<bt709>


=item B<unknown>


=item B<bt470m>


=item B<bt470bg>


=item B<smpte170m>


=item B<smpte240m>


=item B<linear>


=item B<log100>


=item B<log316>


=item B<iec61966-2-4>


=item B<bt1361e>


=item B<iec61966-2-1>


=item B<bt2020-10>


=item B<bt2020-12>


=item B<smpte2084>


=item B<smpte428>


=item B<arib-std-b67>


=back



=item B<colorspace>

Set the colorspace.
Available values are:


=over 4


=item B<auto>

Keep the same colorspace property (default).


=item B<gbr>


=item B<bt709>


=item B<unknown>


=item B<fcc>


=item B<bt470bg>


=item B<smpte170m>


=item B<smpte240m>


=item B<ycgco>


=item B<bt2020nc>


=item B<bt2020c>


=item B<smpte2085>


=item B<chroma-derived-nc>


=item B<chroma-derived-c>


=item B<ictcp>


=back


=back



=head2 shear

Apply shear transform to input video.

This filter supports the following options:


=over 4


=item B<shx>

Shear factor in X-direction. Default value is 0.
Allowed range is from -2 to 2.


=item B<shy>

Shear factor in Y-direction. Default value is 0.
Allowed range is from -2 to 2.


=item B<fillcolor, c>

Set the color used to fill the output area not covered by the transformed
video. For the general syntax of this option, check the
B<"Color" section in the ffmpeg-utils manual>.
If the special value "none" is selected then no
background is printed (useful for example if the background is never shown).

Default value is "black".


=item B<interp>

Set interpolation type. Can be C<bilinear> or C<nearest>. Default is C<bilinear>.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head2 showinfo


Show a line containing various information for each input video frame.
The input video is not modified.

This filter supports the following options:


=over 4


=item B<checksum>

Calculate checksums of each plane. By default enabled.

=back


The shown line contains a sequence of key/value pairs of the form
I<key>:I<value>.

The following values are shown in the output:


=over 4


=item B<n>

The (sequential) number of the input frame, starting from 0.


=item B<pts>

The Presentation TimeStamp of the input frame, expressed as a number of
time base units. The time base unit depends on the filter input pad.


=item B<pts_time>

The Presentation TimeStamp of the input frame, expressed as a number of
seconds.


=item B<pos>

The position of the frame in the input stream, or -1 if this information is
unavailable and/or meaningless (for example in case of synthetic video).


=item B<fmt>

The pixel format name.


=item B<sar>

The sample aspect ratio of the input frame, expressed in the form
I<num>/I<den>.


=item B<s>

The size of the input frame. For the syntax of this option, check the
B<"Video size" section in the ffmpeg-utils manual>.


=item B<i>

The type of interlaced mode ("P" for "progressive", "T" for top field first, "B"
for bottom field first).


=item B<iskey>

This is 1 if the frame is a key frame, 0 otherwise.


=item B<type>

The picture type of the input frame ("I" for an I-frame, "P" for a
P-frame, "B" for a B-frame, or "?" for an unknown type).
Also refer to the documentation of the C<AVPictureType> enum and of
the C<av_get_picture_type_char> function defined in
F<libavutil/avutil.h>.


=item B<checksum>

The Adler-32 checksum (printed in hexadecimal) of all the planes of the input frame.


=item B<plane_checksum>

The Adler-32 checksum (printed in hexadecimal) of each plane of the input frame,
expressed in the form "[I<c0> I<c1> I<c2> I<c3>]".


=item B<mean>

The mean value of pixels in each plane of the input frame, expressed in the form
"[I<mean0> I<mean1> I<mean2> I<mean3>]".


=item B<stdev>

The standard deviation of pixel values in each plane of the input frame, expressed
in the form "[I<stdev0> I<stdev1> I<stdev2> I<stdev3>]".


=back



=head2 showpalette


Displays the 256 colors palette of each frame. This filter is only relevant for
I<pal8> pixel format frames.

It accepts the following option:


=over 4


=item B<s>

Set the size of the box used to represent one palette color entry. Default is
C<30> (for a C<30x30> pixel box).

=back



=head2 shuffleframes


Reorder and/or duplicate and/or drop video frames.

It accepts the following parameters:


=over 4


=item B<mapping>

Set the destination indexes of input frames.
This is space or '|' separated list of indexes that maps input frames to output
frames. Number of indexes also sets maximal value that each index may have.
'-1' index have special meaning and that is to drop frame.

=back


The first frame has the index 0. The default is to keep the input unchanged.


=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Swap second and third frame of every three frames of the input:
	
	ffmpeg -i INPUT -vf "shuffleframes=0 2 1" OUTPUT



=item *

Swap 10th and 1st frame of every ten frames of the input:
	
	ffmpeg -i INPUT -vf "shuffleframes=9 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 0" OUTPUT


=back



=head2 shufflepixels


Reorder pixels in video frames.

This filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<direction, d>

Set shuffle direction. Can be forward or inverse direction.
Default direction is forward.


=item B<mode, m>

Set shuffle mode. Can be horizontal, vertical or block mode.


=item B<width, w>


=item B<height, h>

Set shuffle block_size. In case of horizontal shuffle mode only width
part of size is used, and in case of vertical shuffle mode only height
part of size is used.


=item B<seed, s>

Set random seed used with shuffling pixels. Mainly useful to set to be able
to reverse filtering process to get original input.
For example, to reverse forward shuffle you need to use same parameters
and exact same seed and to set direction to inverse.

=back



=head2 shuffleplanes


Reorder and/or duplicate video planes.

It accepts the following parameters:


=over 4



=item B<map0>

The index of the input plane to be used as the first output plane.


=item B<map1>

The index of the input plane to be used as the second output plane.


=item B<map2>

The index of the input plane to be used as the third output plane.


=item B<map3>

The index of the input plane to be used as the fourth output plane.


=back


The first plane has the index 0. The default is to keep the input unchanged.


=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Swap the second and third planes of the input:
	
	ffmpeg -i INPUT -vf shuffleplanes=0:2:1:3 OUTPUT


=back




=head2 signalstats

Evaluate various visual metrics that assist in determining issues associated
with the digitization of analog video media.

By default the filter will log these metadata values:


=over 4


=item B<YMIN>

Display the minimal Y value contained within the input frame. Expressed in
range of [0-255].


=item B<YLOW>

Display the Y value at the 10% percentile within the input frame. Expressed in
range of [0-255].


=item B<YAVG>

Display the average Y value within the input frame. Expressed in range of
[0-255].


=item B<YHIGH>

Display the Y value at the 90% percentile within the input frame. Expressed in
range of [0-255].


=item B<YMAX>

Display the maximum Y value contained within the input frame. Expressed in
range of [0-255].


=item B<UMIN>

Display the minimal U value contained within the input frame. Expressed in
range of [0-255].


=item B<ULOW>

Display the U value at the 10% percentile within the input frame. Expressed in
range of [0-255].


=item B<UAVG>

Display the average U value within the input frame. Expressed in range of
[0-255].


=item B<UHIGH>

Display the U value at the 90% percentile within the input frame. Expressed in
range of [0-255].


=item B<UMAX>

Display the maximum U value contained within the input frame. Expressed in
range of [0-255].


=item B<VMIN>

Display the minimal V value contained within the input frame. Expressed in
range of [0-255].


=item B<VLOW>

Display the V value at the 10% percentile within the input frame. Expressed in
range of [0-255].


=item B<VAVG>

Display the average V value within the input frame. Expressed in range of
[0-255].


=item B<VHIGH>

Display the V value at the 90% percentile within the input frame. Expressed in
range of [0-255].


=item B<VMAX>

Display the maximum V value contained within the input frame. Expressed in
range of [0-255].


=item B<SATMIN>

Display the minimal saturation value contained within the input frame.
Expressed in range of [0-~181.02].


=item B<SATLOW>

Display the saturation value at the 10% percentile within the input frame.
Expressed in range of [0-~181.02].


=item B<SATAVG>

Display the average saturation value within the input frame. Expressed in range
of [0-~181.02].


=item B<SATHIGH>

Display the saturation value at the 90% percentile within the input frame.
Expressed in range of [0-~181.02].


=item B<SATMAX>

Display the maximum saturation value contained within the input frame.
Expressed in range of [0-~181.02].


=item B<HUEMED>

Display the median value for hue within the input frame. Expressed in range of
[0-360].


=item B<HUEAVG>

Display the average value for hue within the input frame. Expressed in range of
[0-360].


=item B<YDIF>

Display the average of sample value difference between all values of the Y
plane in the current frame and corresponding values of the previous input frame.
Expressed in range of [0-255].


=item B<UDIF>

Display the average of sample value difference between all values of the U
plane in the current frame and corresponding values of the previous input frame.
Expressed in range of [0-255].


=item B<VDIF>

Display the average of sample value difference between all values of the V
plane in the current frame and corresponding values of the previous input frame.
Expressed in range of [0-255].


=item B<YBITDEPTH>

Display bit depth of Y plane in current frame.
Expressed in range of [0-16].


=item B<UBITDEPTH>

Display bit depth of U plane in current frame.
Expressed in range of [0-16].


=item B<VBITDEPTH>

Display bit depth of V plane in current frame.
Expressed in range of [0-16].

=back


The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<stat>


=item B<out>


B<stat> specify an additional form of image analysis.
B<out> output video with the specified type of pixel highlighted.

Both options accept the following values:


=over 4


=item B<tout>

Identify I<temporal outliers> pixels. A I<temporal outlier> is a pixel
unlike the neighboring pixels of the same field. Examples of temporal outliers
include the results of video dropouts, head clogs, or tape tracking issues.


=item B<vrep>

Identify I<vertical line repetition>. Vertical line repetition includes
similar rows of pixels within a frame. In born-digital video vertical line
repetition is common, but this pattern is uncommon in video digitized from an
analog source. When it occurs in video that results from the digitization of an
analog source it can indicate concealment from a dropout compensator.


=item B<brng>

Identify pixels that fall outside of legal broadcast range.

=back



=item B<color, c>

Set the highlight color for the B<out> option. The default color is
yellow.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Output data of various video metrics:
	
	ffprobe -f lavfi movie=example.mov,signalstats="stat=tout+vrep+brng" -show_frames



=item *

Output specific data about the minimum and maximum values of the Y plane per frame:
	
	ffprobe -f lavfi movie=example.mov,signalstats -show_entries frame_tags=lavfi.signalstats.YMAX,lavfi.signalstats.YMIN



=item *

Playback video while highlighting pixels that are outside of broadcast range in red.
	
	ffplay example.mov -vf signalstats="out=brng:color=red"



=item *

Playback video with signalstats metadata drawn over the frame.
	
	ffplay example.mov -vf signalstats=stat=brng+vrep+tout,drawtext=fontfile=FreeSerif.ttf:textfile=signalstat_drawtext.txt


The contents of signalstat_drawtext.txt used in the command are:
	
	time %{pts:hms}
	Y (%{metadata:lavfi.signalstats.YMIN}-%{metadata:lavfi.signalstats.YMAX})
	U (%{metadata:lavfi.signalstats.UMIN}-%{metadata:lavfi.signalstats.UMAX})
	V (%{metadata:lavfi.signalstats.VMIN}-%{metadata:lavfi.signalstats.VMAX})
	saturation maximum: %{metadata:lavfi.signalstats.SATMAX}
	


=back




=head2 signature


Calculates the MPEG-7 Video Signature. The filter can handle more than one
input. In this case the matching between the inputs can be calculated additionally.
The filter always passes through the first input. The signature of each stream can
be written into a file.

It accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<detectmode>

Enable or disable the matching process.

Available values are:


=over 4


=item B<off>

Disable the calculation of a matching (default).

=item B<full>

Calculate the matching for the whole video and output whether the whole video
matches or only parts.

=item B<fast>

Calculate only until a matching is found or the video ends. Should be faster in
some cases.

=back



=item B<nb_inputs>

Set the number of inputs. The option value must be a non negative integer.
Default value is 1.


=item B<filename>

Set the path to which the output is written. If there is more than one input,
the path must be a prototype, i.e. must contain %d or %0nd (where n is a positive
integer), that will be replaced with the input number. If no filename is
specified, no output will be written. This is the default.


=item B<format>

Choose the output format.

Available values are:


=over 4


=item B<binary>

Use the specified binary representation (default).

=item B<xml>

Use the specified xml representation.

=back



=item B<th_d>

Set threshold to detect one word as similar. The option value must be an integer
greater than zero. The default value is 9000.


=item B<th_dc>

Set threshold to detect all words as similar. The option value must be an integer
greater than zero. The default value is 60000.


=item B<th_xh>

Set threshold to detect frames as similar. The option value must be an integer
greater than zero. The default value is 116.


=item B<th_di>

Set the minimum length of a sequence in frames to recognize it as matching
sequence. The option value must be a non negative integer value.
The default value is 0.


=item B<th_it>

Set the minimum relation, that matching frames to all frames must have.
The option value must be a double value between 0 and 1. The default value is 0.5.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

To calculate the signature of an input video and store it in signature.bin:
	
	ffmpeg -i input.mkv -vf signature=filename=signature.bin -map 0:v -f null -



=item *

To detect whether two videos match and store the signatures in XML format in
signature0.xml and signature1.xml:
	
	ffmpeg -i input1.mkv -i input2.mkv -filter_complex "[0:v][1:v] signature=nb_inputs=2:detectmode=full:format=xml:filename=signature%d.xml" -map :v -f null -



=back




=head2 smartblur


Blur the input video without impacting the outlines.

It accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<luma_radius, lr>

Set the luma radius. The option value must be a float number in
the range [0.1,5.0] that specifies the variance of the gaussian filter
used to blur the image (slower if larger). Default value is 1.0.


=item B<luma_strength, ls>

Set the luma strength. The option value must be a float number
in the range [-1.0,1.0] that configures the blurring. A value included
in [0.0,1.0] will blur the image whereas a value included in
[-1.0,0.0] will sharpen the image. Default value is 1.0.


=item B<luma_threshold, lt>

Set the luma threshold used as a coefficient to determine
whether a pixel should be blurred or not. The option value must be an
integer in the range [-30,30]. A value of 0 will filter all the image,
a value included in [0,30] will filter flat areas and a value included
in [-30,0] will filter edges. Default value is 0.


=item B<chroma_radius, cr>

Set the chroma radius. The option value must be a float number in
the range [0.1,5.0] that specifies the variance of the gaussian filter
used to blur the image (slower if larger). Default value is B<luma_radius>.


=item B<chroma_strength, cs>

Set the chroma strength. The option value must be a float number
in the range [-1.0,1.0] that configures the blurring. A value included
in [0.0,1.0] will blur the image whereas a value included in
[-1.0,0.0] will sharpen the image. Default value is B<luma_strength>.


=item B<chroma_threshold, ct>

Set the chroma threshold used as a coefficient to determine
whether a pixel should be blurred or not. The option value must be an
integer in the range [-30,30]. A value of 0 will filter all the image,
a value included in [0,30] will filter flat areas and a value included
in [-30,0] will filter edges. Default value is B<luma_threshold>.

=back


If a chroma option is not explicitly set, the corresponding luma value
is set.


=head2 sobel

Apply sobel operator to input video stream.

The filter accepts the following option:


=over 4


=item B<planes>

Set which planes will be processed, unprocessed planes will be copied.
By default value 0xf, all planes will be processed.


=item B<scale>

Set value which will be multiplied with filtered result.


=item B<delta>

Set value which will be added to filtered result.

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.



=head2 spp


Apply a simple postprocessing filter that compresses and decompresses the image
at several (or - in the case of B<quality> level C<6> - all) shifts
and average the results.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<quality>

Set quality. This option defines the number of levels for averaging. It accepts
an integer in the range 0-6. If set to C<0>, the filter will have no
effect. A value of C<6> means the higher quality. For each increment of
that value the speed drops by a factor of approximately 2.  Default value is
C<3>.


=item B<qp>

Force a constant quantization parameter. If not set, the filter will use the QP
from the video stream (if available).


=item B<mode>

Set thresholding mode. Available modes are:


=over 4


=item B<hard>

Set hard thresholding (default).

=item B<soft>

Set soft thresholding (better de-ringing effect, but likely blurrier).

=back



=item B<use_bframe_qp>

Enable the use of the QP from the B-Frames if set to C<1>. Using this
option may cause flicker since the B-Frames have often larger QP. Default is
C<0> (not enabled).

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the following commands:

=over 4


=item B<quality, level>

Set quality level. The value C<max> can be used to set the maximum level,
currently C<6>.

=back




=head2 sr


Scale the input by applying one of the super-resolution methods based on
convolutional neural networks. Supported models:


=over 4


=item *

Super-Resolution Convolutional Neural Network model (SRCNN).
See E<lt>B<https://arxiv.org/abs/1501.00092>E<gt>.


=item *

Efficient Sub-Pixel Convolutional Neural Network model (ESPCN).
See E<lt>B<https://arxiv.org/abs/1609.05158>E<gt>.

=back


Training scripts as well as scripts for model file (.pb) saving can be found at
E<lt>B<https://github.com/XueweiMeng/sr/tree/sr_dnn_native>E<gt>. Original repository
is at E<lt>B<https://github.com/HighVoltageRocknRoll/sr.git>E<gt>.

Native model files (.model) can be generated from TensorFlow model
files (.pb) by using tools/python/convert.py

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<dnn_backend>

Specify which DNN backend to use for model loading and execution. This option accepts
the following values:


=over 4


=item B<native>

Native implementation of DNN loading and execution.


=item B<tensorflow>

TensorFlow backend. To enable this backend you
need to install the TensorFlow for C library (see
E<lt>B<https://www.tensorflow.org/install/install_c>E<gt>) and configure FFmpeg with
C<--enable-libtensorflow>

=back


Default value is B<native>.


=item B<model>

Set path to model file specifying network architecture and its parameters.
Note that different backends use different file formats. TensorFlow backend
can load files for both formats, while native backend can load files for only
its format.


=item B<scale_factor>

Set scale factor for SRCNN model. Allowed values are C<2>, C<3> and C<4>.
Default value is C<2>. Scale factor is necessary for SRCNN model, because it accepts
input upscaled using bicubic upscaling with proper scale factor.

=back


This feature can also be finished with B<dnn_processing> filter.


=head2 ssim


Obtain the SSIM (Structural SImilarity Metric) between two input videos.

This filter takes in input two input videos, the first input is
considered the "main" source and is passed unchanged to the
output. The second input is used as a "reference" video for computing
the SSIM.

Both video inputs must have the same resolution and pixel format for
this filter to work correctly. Also it assumes that both inputs
have the same number of frames, which are compared one by one.

The filter stores the calculated SSIM of each frame.

The description of the accepted parameters follows.


=over 4


=item B<stats_file, f>

If specified the filter will use the named file to save the SSIM of
each individual frame. When filename equals "-" the data is sent to
standard output.

=back


The file printed if I<stats_file> is selected, contains a sequence of
key/value pairs of the form I<key>:I<value> for each compared
couple of frames.

A description of each shown parameter follows:


=over 4


=item B<n>

sequential number of the input frame, starting from 1


=item B<Y, U, V, R, G, B>

SSIM of the compared frames for the component specified by the suffix.


=item B<All>

SSIM of the compared frames for the whole frame.


=item B<dB>

Same as above but in dB representation.

=back


This filter also supports the B<framesync> options.


=head3 Examples


=over 4


=item *

For example:
	
	movie=ref_movie.mpg, setpts=PTS-STARTPTS [main];
	[main][ref] ssim="stats_file=stats.log" [out]


On this example the input file being processed is compared with the
reference file F<ref_movie.mpg>. The SSIM of each individual frame
is stored in F<stats.log>.


=item *

Another example with both psnr and ssim at same time:
	
	ffmpeg -i main.mpg -i ref.mpg -lavfi  "ssim;[0:v][1:v]psnr" -f null -



=item *

Another example with different containers:
	
	ffmpeg -i main.mpg -i ref.mkv -lavfi  "[0:v]settb=AVTB,setpts=PTS-STARTPTS[main];[1:v]settb=AVTB,setpts=PTS-STARTPTS[ref];[main][ref]ssim" -f null -


=back



=head2 stereo3d


Convert between different stereoscopic image formats.

The filters accept the following options:


=over 4


=item B<in>

Set stereoscopic image format of input.

Available values for input image formats are:

=over 4


=item B<sbsl>

side by side parallel (left eye left, right eye right)


=item B<sbsr>

side by side crosseye (right eye left, left eye right)


=item B<sbs2l>

side by side parallel with half width resolution
(left eye left, right eye right)


=item B<sbs2r>

side by side crosseye with half width resolution
(right eye left, left eye right)


=item B<abl>


=item B<tbl>

above-below (left eye above, right eye below)


=item B<abr>


=item B<tbr>

above-below (right eye above, left eye below)


=item B<ab2l>


=item B<tb2l>

above-below with half height resolution
(left eye above, right eye below)


=item B<ab2r>


=item B<tb2r>

above-below with half height resolution
(right eye above, left eye below)


=item B<al>

alternating frames (left eye first, right eye second)


=item B<ar>

alternating frames (right eye first, left eye second)


=item B<irl>

interleaved rows (left eye has top row, right eye starts on next row)


=item B<irr>

interleaved rows (right eye has top row, left eye starts on next row)


=item B<icl>

interleaved columns, left eye first


=item B<icr>

interleaved columns, right eye first

Default value is B<sbsl>.

=back



=item B<out>

Set stereoscopic image format of output.


=over 4


=item B<sbsl>

side by side parallel (left eye left, right eye right)


=item B<sbsr>

side by side crosseye (right eye left, left eye right)


=item B<sbs2l>

side by side parallel with half width resolution
(left eye left, right eye right)


=item B<sbs2r>

side by side crosseye with half width resolution
(right eye left, left eye right)


=item B<abl>


=item B<tbl>

above-below (left eye above, right eye below)


=item B<abr>


=item B<tbr>

above-below (right eye above, left eye below)


=item B<ab2l>


=item B<tb2l>

above-below with half height resolution
(left eye above, right eye below)


=item B<ab2r>


=item B<tb2r>

above-below with half height resolution
(right eye above, left eye below)


=item B<al>

alternating frames (left eye first, right eye second)


=item B<ar>

alternating frames (right eye first, left eye second)


=item B<irl>

interleaved rows (left eye has top row, right eye starts on next row)


=item B<irr>

interleaved rows (right eye has top row, left eye starts on next row)


=item B<arbg>

anaglyph red/blue gray
(red filter on left eye, blue filter on right eye)


=item B<argg>

anaglyph red/green gray
(red filter on left eye, green filter on right eye)


=item B<arcg>

anaglyph red/cyan gray
(red filter on left eye, cyan filter on right eye)


=item B<arch>

anaglyph red/cyan half colored
(red filter on left eye, cyan filter on right eye)


=item B<arcc>

anaglyph red/cyan color
(red filter on left eye, cyan filter on right eye)


=item B<arcd>

anaglyph red/cyan color optimized with the least squares projection of dubois
(red filter on left eye, cyan filter on right eye)


=item B<agmg>

anaglyph green/magenta gray
(green filter on left eye, magenta filter on right eye)


=item B<agmh>

anaglyph green/magenta half colored
(green filter on left eye, magenta filter on right eye)


=item B<agmc>

anaglyph green/magenta colored
(green filter on left eye, magenta filter on right eye)


=item B<agmd>

anaglyph green/magenta color optimized with the least squares projection of dubois
(green filter on left eye, magenta filter on right eye)


=item B<aybg>

anaglyph yellow/blue gray
(yellow filter on left eye, blue filter on right eye)


=item B<aybh>

anaglyph yellow/blue half colored
(yellow filter on left eye, blue filter on right eye)


=item B<aybc>

anaglyph yellow/blue colored
(yellow filter on left eye, blue filter on right eye)


=item B<aybd>

anaglyph yellow/blue color optimized with the least squares projection of dubois
(yellow filter on left eye, blue filter on right eye)


=item B<ml>

mono output (left eye only)


=item B<mr>

mono output (right eye only)


=item B<chl>

checkerboard, left eye first


=item B<chr>

checkerboard, right eye first


=item B<icl>

interleaved columns, left eye first


=item B<icr>

interleaved columns, right eye first


=item B<hdmi>

HDMI frame pack

=back


Default value is B<arcd>.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Convert input video from side by side parallel to anaglyph yellow/blue dubois:
	
	stereo3d=sbsl:aybd



=item *

Convert input video from above below (left eye above, right eye below) to side by side crosseye.
	
	stereo3d=abl:sbsr


=back



=head2 streamselect, astreamselect

Select video or audio streams.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<inputs>

Set number of inputs. Default is 2.


=item B<map>

Set input indexes to remap to outputs.

=back



=head3 Commands


The C<streamselect> and C<astreamselect> filter supports the following
commands:


=over 4


=item B<map>

Set input indexes to remap to outputs.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Select first 5 seconds 1st stream and rest of time 2nd stream:
	
	sendcmd='5.0 streamselect map 1',streamselect=inputs=2:map=0



=item *

Same as above, but for audio:
	
	asendcmd='5.0 astreamselect map 1',astreamselect=inputs=2:map=0


=back




=head2 subtitles


Draw subtitles on top of input video using the libass library.

To enable compilation of this filter you need to configure FFmpeg with
C<--enable-libass>. This filter also requires a build with libavcodec and
libavformat to convert the passed subtitles file to ASS (Advanced Substation
Alpha) subtitles format.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<filename, f>

Set the filename of the subtitle file to read. It must be specified.


=item B<original_size>

Specify the size of the original video, the video for which the ASS file
was composed. For the syntax of this option, check the
B<"Video size" section in the ffmpeg-utils manual>.
Due to a misdesign in ASS aspect ratio arithmetic, this is necessary to
correctly scale the fonts if the aspect ratio has been changed.


=item B<fontsdir>

Set a directory path containing fonts that can be used by the filter.
These fonts will be used in addition to whatever the font provider uses.


=item B<alpha>

Process alpha channel, by default alpha channel is untouched.


=item B<charenc>

Set subtitles input character encoding. C<subtitles> filter only. Only
useful if not UTF-8.


=item B<stream_index, si>

Set subtitles stream index. C<subtitles> filter only.


=item B<force_style>

Override default style or script info parameters of the subtitles. It accepts a
string containing ASS style format C<KEY=VALUE> couples separated by ",".

=back


If the first key is not specified, it is assumed that the first value
specifies the B<filename>.

For example, to render the file F<sub.srt> on top of the input
video, use the command:
	
	subtitles=sub.srt


which is equivalent to:
	
	subtitles=filename=sub.srt


To render the default subtitles stream from file F<video.mkv>, use:
	
	subtitles=video.mkv


To render the second subtitles stream from that file, use:
	
	subtitles=video.mkv:si=1


To make the subtitles stream from F<sub.srt> appear in 80% transparent blue
C<DejaVu Serif>, use:
	
	subtitles=sub.srt:force_style='Fontname=DejaVu Serif,PrimaryColour=&HCCFF0000'



=head2 super2xsai


Scale the input by 2x and smooth using the Super2xSaI (Scale and
Interpolate) pixel art scaling algorithm.

Useful for enlarging pixel art images without reducing sharpness.


=head2 swaprect


Swap two rectangular objects in video.

This filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<w>

Set object width.


=item B<h>

Set object height.


=item B<x1>

Set 1st rect x coordinate.


=item B<y1>

Set 1st rect y coordinate.


=item B<x2>

Set 2nd rect x coordinate.


=item B<y2>

Set 2nd rect y coordinate.

All expressions are evaluated once for each frame.

=back


The all options are expressions containing the following constants:


=over 4


=item B<w>


=item B<h>

The input width and height.


=item B<a>

same as I<w> / I<h>


=item B<sar>

input sample aspect ratio


=item B<dar>

input display aspect ratio, it is the same as (I<w> / I<h>) * I<sar>


=item B<n>

The number of the input frame, starting from 0.


=item B<t>

The timestamp expressed in seconds. It's NAN if the input timestamp is unknown.


=item B<pos>

the position in the file of the input frame, NAN if unknown

=back



=head3 Commands


This filter supports the all above options as B<commands>.


=head2 swapuv

Swap U & V plane.


=head2 tblend

Blend successive video frames.

See B<blend>


=head2 telecine


Apply telecine process to the video.

This filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<first_field>


=over 4


=item B<top, t>

top field first

=item B<bottom, b>

bottom field first
The default value is C<top>.

=back



=item B<pattern>

A string of numbers representing the pulldown pattern you wish to apply.
The default value is C<23>.

=back


	
	Some typical patterns:
	
	NTSC output (30i):
	27.5p: 32222
	24p: 23 (classic)
	24p: 2332 (preferred)
	20p: 33
	18p: 334
	16p: 3444
	
	PAL output (25i):
	27.5p: 12222
	24p: 222222222223 ("Euro pulldown")
	16.67p: 33
	16p: 33333334



=head2 thistogram


Compute and draw a color distribution histogram for the input video across time.

Unlike B<histogram> video filter which only shows histogram of single input frame
at certain time, this filter shows also past histograms of number of frames defined
by C<width> option.

The computed histogram is a representation of the color component
distribution in an image.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<width, w>

Set width of single color component output. Default value is C<0>.
Value of C<0> means width will be picked from input video.
This also set number of passed histograms to keep.
Allowed range is [0, 8192].


=item B<display_mode, d>

Set display mode.
It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<stack>

Per color component graphs are placed below each other.


=item B<parade>

Per color component graphs are placed side by side.


=item B<overlay>

Presents information identical to that in the C<parade>, except
that the graphs representing color components are superimposed directly
over one another.

=back

Default is C<stack>.


=item B<levels_mode, m>

Set mode. Can be either C<linear>, or C<logarithmic>.
Default is C<linear>.


=item B<components, c>

Set what color components to display.
Default is C<7>.


=item B<bgopacity, b>

Set background opacity. Default is C<0.9>.


=item B<envelope, e>

Show envelope. Default is disabled.


=item B<ecolor, ec>

Set envelope color. Default is C<gold>.


=item B<slide>

Set slide mode.

Available values for slide is:

=over 4


=item B<frame>

Draw new frame when right border is reached.


=item B<replace>

Replace old columns with new ones.


=item B<scroll>

Scroll from right to left.


=item B<rscroll>

Scroll from left to right.


=item B<picture>

Draw single picture.

=back


Default is C<replace>.

=back



=head2 threshold


Apply threshold effect to video stream.

This filter needs four video streams to perform thresholding.
First stream is stream we are filtering.
Second stream is holding threshold values, third stream is holding min values,
and last, fourth stream is holding max values.

The filter accepts the following option:


=over 4


=item B<planes>

Set which planes will be processed, unprocessed planes will be copied.
By default value 0xf, all planes will be processed.

=back


For example if first stream pixel's component value is less then threshold value
of pixel component from 2nd threshold stream, third stream value will picked,
otherwise fourth stream pixel component value will be picked.

Using color source filter one can perform various types of thresholding:


=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Binary threshold, using gray color as threshold:
	
	ffmpeg -i 320x240.avi -f lavfi -i color=gray -f lavfi -i color=black -f lavfi -i color=white -lavfi threshold output.avi



=item *

Inverted binary threshold, using gray color as threshold:
	
	ffmpeg -i 320x240.avi -f lavfi -i color=gray -f lavfi -i color=white -f lavfi -i color=black -lavfi threshold output.avi



=item *

Truncate binary threshold, using gray color as threshold:
	
	ffmpeg -i 320x240.avi -f lavfi -i color=gray -i 320x240.avi -f lavfi -i color=gray -lavfi threshold output.avi



=item *

Threshold to zero, using gray color as threshold:
	
	ffmpeg -i 320x240.avi -f lavfi -i color=gray -f lavfi -i color=white -i 320x240.avi -lavfi threshold output.avi



=item *

Inverted threshold to zero, using gray color as threshold:
	
	ffmpeg -i 320x240.avi -f lavfi -i color=gray -i 320x240.avi -f lavfi -i color=white -lavfi threshold output.avi


=back



=head2 thumbnail

Select the most representative frame in a given sequence of consecutive frames.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<n>

Set the frames batch size to analyze; in a set of I<n> frames, the filter
will pick one of them, and then handle the next batch of I<n> frames until
the end. Default is C<100>.

=back


Since the filter keeps track of the whole frames sequence, a bigger I<n>
value will result in a higher memory usage, so a high value is not recommended.


=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Extract one picture each 50 frames:
	
	thumbnail=50



=item *

Complete example of a thumbnail creation with B<ffmpeg>:
	
	ffmpeg -i in.avi -vf thumbnail,scale=300:200 -frames:v 1 out.png


=back




=head2 tile


Tile several successive frames together.

The B<untile> filter can do the reverse.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4



=item B<layout>

Set the grid size (i.e. the number of lines and columns). For the syntax of
this option, check the
B<"Video size" section in the ffmpeg-utils manual>.


=item B<nb_frames>

Set the maximum number of frames to render in the given area. It must be less
than or equal to I<w>xI<h>. The default value is C<0>, meaning all
the area will be used.


=item B<margin>

Set the outer border margin in pixels.


=item B<padding>

Set the inner border thickness (i.e. the number of pixels between frames). For
more advanced padding options (such as having different values for the edges),
refer to the pad video filter.


=item B<color>

Specify the color of the unused area. For the syntax of this option, check the
B<"Color" section in the ffmpeg-utils manual>.
The default value of I<color> is "black".


=item B<overlap>

Set the number of frames to overlap when tiling several successive frames together.
The value must be between C<0> and I<nb_frames - 1>.


=item B<init_padding>

Set the number of frames to initially be empty before displaying first output frame.
This controls how soon will one get first output frame.
The value must be between C<0> and I<nb_frames - 1>.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Produce 8x8 PNG tiles of all keyframes (B<-skip_frame nokey>) in a movie:
	
	ffmpeg -skip_frame nokey -i file.avi -vf 'scale=128:72,tile=8x8' -an -vsync 0 keyframes%03d.png

The B<-vsync 0> is necessary to prevent B<ffmpeg> from
duplicating each output frame to accommodate the originally detected frame
rate.


=item *

Display C<5> pictures in an area of C<3x2> frames,
with C<7> pixels between them, and C<2> pixels of initial margin, using
mixed flat and named options:
	
	tile=3x2:nb_frames=5:padding=7:margin=2


=back



=head2 tinterlace


Perform various types of temporal field interlacing.

Frames are counted starting from 1, so the first input frame is
considered odd.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4



=item B<mode>

Specify the mode of the interlacing. This option can also be specified
as a value alone. See below for a list of values for this option.

Available values are:


=over 4


=item B<merge, 0>

Move odd frames into the upper field, even into the lower field,
generating a double height frame at half frame rate.
	
	 ------> time
	Input:
	Frame 1         Frame 2         Frame 3         Frame 4
	
	11111           22222           33333           44444
	11111           22222           33333           44444
	11111           22222           33333           44444
	11111           22222           33333           44444
	
	Output:
	11111                           33333
	22222                           44444
	11111                           33333
	22222                           44444
	11111                           33333
	22222                           44444
	11111                           33333
	22222                           44444



=item B<drop_even, 1>

Only output odd frames, even frames are dropped, generating a frame with
unchanged height at half frame rate.

	
	 ------> time
	Input:
	Frame 1         Frame 2         Frame 3         Frame 4
	
	11111           22222           33333           44444
	11111           22222           33333           44444
	11111           22222           33333           44444
	11111           22222           33333           44444
	
	Output:
	11111                           33333
	11111                           33333
	11111                           33333
	11111                           33333



=item B<drop_odd, 2>

Only output even frames, odd frames are dropped, generating a frame with
unchanged height at half frame rate.

	
	 ------> time
	Input:
	Frame 1         Frame 2         Frame 3         Frame 4
	
	11111           22222           33333           44444
	11111           22222           33333           44444
	11111           22222           33333           44444
	11111           22222           33333           44444
	
	Output:
	                22222                           44444
	                22222                           44444
	                22222                           44444
