The count of the input frame for video or the number of consumed samples,
not including the current frame for audio, starting from 0.


=item B<NB_CONSUMED_SAMPLES>

The number of consumed samples, not including the current frame (only
audio)


=item B<NB_SAMPLES, S>

The number of samples in the current frame (only audio)


=item B<SAMPLE_RATE, SR>

The audio sample rate.


=item B<STARTPTS>

The PTS of the first frame.


=item B<STARTT>

the time in seconds of the first frame


=item B<INTERLACED>

State whether the current frame is interlaced.


=item B<T>

the time in seconds of the current frame


=item B<POS>

original position in the file of the frame, or undefined if undefined
for the current frame


=item B<PREV_INPTS>

The previous input PTS.


=item B<PREV_INT>

previous input time in seconds


=item B<PREV_OUTPTS>

The previous output PTS.


=item B<PREV_OUTT>

previous output time in seconds


=item B<RTCTIME>

The wallclock (RTC) time in microseconds. This is deprecated, use time(0)
instead.


=item B<RTCSTART>

The wallclock (RTC) time at the start of the movie in microseconds.


=item B<TB>

The timebase of the input timestamps.


=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Start counting PTS from zero
	
	setpts=PTS-STARTPTS



=item *

Apply fast motion effect:
	
	setpts=0.5*PTS



=item *

Apply slow motion effect:
	
	setpts=2.0*PTS



=item *

Set fixed rate of 25 frames per second:
	
	setpts=N/(25*TB)



=item *

Set fixed rate 25 fps with some jitter:
	
	setpts='1/(25*TB) * (N + 0.05 * sin(N*2*PI/25))'



=item *

Apply an offset of 10 seconds to the input PTS:
	
	setpts=PTS+10/TB



=item *

Generate timestamps from a "live source" and rebase onto the current timebase:
	
	setpts='(RTCTIME - RTCSTART) / (TB * 1000000)'



=item *

Generate timestamps by counting samples:
	
	asetpts=N/SR/TB



=back



=head2 setrange


Force color range for the output video frame.

The C<setrange> filter marks the color range property for the
output frames. It does not change the input frame, but only sets the
corresponding property, which affects how the frame is treated by
following filters.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4



=item B<range>

Available values are:


=over 4


=item B<auto>

Keep the same color range property.


=item B<unspecified, unknown>

Set the color range as unspecified.


=item B<limited, tv, mpeg>

Set the color range as limited.


=item B<full, pc, jpeg>

Set the color range as full.

=back


=back



=head2 settb, asettb


Set the timebase to use for the output frames timestamps.
It is mainly useful for testing timebase configuration.

It accepts the following parameters:


=over 4



=item B<expr, tb>

The expression which is evaluated into the output timebase.


=back


The value for B<tb> is an arithmetic expression representing a
rational. The expression can contain the constants "AVTB" (the default
timebase), "intb" (the input timebase) and "sr" (the sample rate,
audio only). Default value is "intb".


=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Set the timebase to 1/25:
	
	settb=expr=1/25



=item *

Set the timebase to 1/10:
	
	settb=expr=0.1



=item *

Set the timebase to 1001/1000:
	
	settb=1+0.001



=item *

Set the timebase to 2*intb:
	
	settb=2*intb



=item *

Set the default timebase value:
	
	settb=AVTB


=back



=head2 showcqt

Convert input audio to a video output representing frequency spectrum
logarithmically using Brown-Puckette constant Q transform algorithm with
direct frequency domain coefficient calculation (but the transform itself
is not really constant Q, instead the Q factor is actually variable/clamped),
with musical tone scale, from E0 to D#10.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<size, s>

Specify the video size for the output. It must be even. For the syntax of this option,
check the B<"Video size" section in the ffmpeg-utils manual>.
Default value is C<1920x1080>.


=item B<fps, rate, r>

Set the output frame rate. Default value is C<25>.


=item B<bar_h>

Set the bargraph height. It must be even. Default value is C<-1> which
computes the bargraph height automatically.


=item B<axis_h>

Set the axis height. It must be even. Default value is C<-1> which computes
the axis height automatically.


=item B<sono_h>

Set the sonogram height. It must be even. Default value is C<-1> which
computes the sonogram height automatically.


=item B<fullhd>

Set the fullhd resolution. This option is deprecated, use I<size>, I<s>
instead. Default value is C<1>.


=item B<sono_v, volume>

Specify the sonogram volume expression. It can contain variables:

=over 4


=item B<bar_v>

the I<bar_v> evaluated expression

=item B<frequency, freq, f>

the frequency where it is evaluated

=item B<timeclamp, tc>

the value of I<timeclamp> option

=back

and functions:

=over 4


=item B<a_weighting(f)>

A-weighting of equal loudness

=item B<b_weighting(f)>

B-weighting of equal loudness

=item B<c_weighting(f)>

C-weighting of equal loudness.

=back

Default value is C<16>.


=item B<bar_v, volume2>

Specify the bargraph volume expression. It can contain variables:

=over 4


=item B<sono_v>

the I<sono_v> evaluated expression

=item B<frequency, freq, f>

the frequency where it is evaluated

=item B<timeclamp, tc>

the value of I<timeclamp> option

=back

and functions:

=over 4


=item B<a_weighting(f)>

A-weighting of equal loudness

=item B<b_weighting(f)>

B-weighting of equal loudness

=item B<c_weighting(f)>

C-weighting of equal loudness.

=back

Default value is C<sono_v>.


=item B<sono_g, gamma>

Specify the sonogram gamma. Lower gamma makes the spectrum more contrast,
higher gamma makes the spectrum having more range. Default value is C<3>.
Acceptable range is C<[1, 7]>.


=item B<bar_g, gamma2>

Specify the bargraph gamma. Default value is C<1>. Acceptable range is
C<[1, 7]>.


=item B<bar_t>

Specify the bargraph transparency level. Lower value makes the bargraph sharper.
Default value is C<1>. Acceptable range is C<[0, 1]>.


=item B<timeclamp, tc>

Specify the transform timeclamp. At low frequency, there is trade-off between
accuracy in time domain and frequency domain. If timeclamp is lower,
event in time domain is represented more accurately (such as fast bass drum),
otherwise event in frequency domain is represented more accurately
(such as bass guitar). Acceptable range is C<[0.002, 1]>. Default value is C<0.17>.


=item B<attack>

Set attack time in seconds. The default is C<0> (disabled). Otherwise, it
limits future samples by applying asymmetric windowing in time domain, useful
when low latency is required. Accepted range is C<[0, 1]>.


=item B<basefreq>

Specify the transform base frequency. Default value is C<20.01523126408007475>,
which is frequency 50 cents below E0. Acceptable range is C<[10, 100000]>.


=item B<endfreq>

Specify the transform end frequency. Default value is C<20495.59681441799654>,
which is frequency 50 cents above D#10. Acceptable range is C<[10, 100000]>.


=item B<coeffclamp>

This option is deprecated and ignored.


=item B<tlength>

Specify the transform length in time domain. Use this option to control accuracy
trade-off between time domain and frequency domain at every frequency sample.
It can contain variables:

=over 4


=item B<frequency, freq, f>

the frequency where it is evaluated

=item B<timeclamp, tc>

the value of I<timeclamp> option.

=back

Default value is C<384*tc/(384+tc*f)>.


=item B<count>

Specify the transform count for every video frame. Default value is C<6>.
Acceptable range is C<[1, 30]>.


=item B<fcount>

Specify the transform count for every single pixel. Default value is C<0>,
which makes it computed automatically. Acceptable range is C<[0, 10]>.


=item B<fontfile>

Specify font file for use with freetype to draw the axis. If not specified,
use embedded font. Note that drawing with font file or embedded font is not
implemented with custom I<basefreq> and I<endfreq>, use I<axisfile>
option instead.


=item B<font>

Specify fontconfig pattern. This has lower priority than I<fontfile>. The
C<:> in the pattern may be replaced by C<|> to avoid unnecessary
escaping.


=item B<fontcolor>

Specify font color expression. This is arithmetic expression that should return
integer value 0xRRGGBB. It can contain variables:

=over 4


=item B<frequency, freq, f>

the frequency where it is evaluated

=item B<timeclamp, tc>

the value of I<timeclamp> option

=back

and functions:

=over 4


=item B<midi(f)>

midi number of frequency f, some midi numbers: E0(16), C1(24), C2(36), A4(69)

=item B<r(x), g(x), b(x)>

red, green, and blue value of intensity x.

=back

Default value is C<st(0, (midi(f)-59.5)/12);
st(1, if(between(ld(0),0,1), 0.5-0.5*cos(2*PI*ld(0)), 0));
r(1-ld(1)) + b(ld(1))>.


=item B<axisfile>

Specify image file to draw the axis. This option override I<fontfile> and
I<fontcolor> option.


=item B<axis, text>

Enable/disable drawing text to the axis. If it is set to C<0>, drawing to
the axis is disabled, ignoring I<fontfile> and I<axisfile> option.
Default value is C<1>.


=item B<csp>

Set colorspace. The accepted values are:

=over 4


=item B<unspecified>

Unspecified (default)


=item B<bt709>

BT.709


=item B<fcc>

FCC


=item B<bt470bg>

BT.470BG or BT.601-6 625


=item B<smpte170m>

SMPTE-170M or BT.601-6 525


=item B<smpte240m>

SMPTE-240M


=item B<bt2020ncl>

BT.2020 with non-constant luminance


=back



=item B<cscheme>

Set spectrogram color scheme. This is list of floating point values with format
C<left_r|left_g|left_b|right_r|right_g|right_b>.
The default is C<1|0.5|0|0|0.5|1>.


=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Playing audio while showing the spectrum:
	
	ffplay -f lavfi 'amovie=a.mp3, asplit [a][out1]; [a] showcqt [out0]'



=item *

Same as above, but with frame rate 30 fps:
	
	ffplay -f lavfi 'amovie=a.mp3, asplit [a][out1]; [a] showcqt=fps=30:count=5 [out0]'



=item *

Playing at 1280x720:
	
	ffplay -f lavfi 'amovie=a.mp3, asplit [a][out1]; [a] showcqt=s=1280x720:count=4 [out0]'



=item *

Disable sonogram display:
	
	sono_h=0



=item *

A1 and its harmonics: A1, A2, (near)E3, A3:
	
	ffplay -f lavfi 'aevalsrc=0.1*sin(2*PI*55*t)+0.1*sin(4*PI*55*t)+0.1*sin(6*PI*55*t)+0.1*sin(8*PI*55*t),
	                 asplit[a][out1]; [a] showcqt [out0]'



=item *

Same as above, but with more accuracy in frequency domain:
	
	ffplay -f lavfi 'aevalsrc=0.1*sin(2*PI*55*t)+0.1*sin(4*PI*55*t)+0.1*sin(6*PI*55*t)+0.1*sin(8*PI*55*t),
	                 asplit[a][out1]; [a] showcqt=timeclamp=0.5 [out0]'



=item *

Custom volume:
	
	bar_v=10:sono_v=bar_v*a_weighting(f)



=item *

Custom gamma, now spectrum is linear to the amplitude.
	
	bar_g=2:sono_g=2



=item *

Custom tlength equation:
	
	tc=0.33:tlength='st(0,0.17); 384*tc / (384 / ld(0) + tc*f /(1-ld(0))) + 384*tc / (tc*f / ld(0) + 384 /(1-ld(0)))'



=item *

Custom fontcolor and fontfile, C-note is colored green, others are colored blue:
	
	fontcolor='if(mod(floor(midi(f)+0.5),12), 0x0000FF, g(1))':fontfile=myfont.ttf



=item *

Custom font using fontconfig:
	
	font='Courier New,Monospace,mono|bold'



=item *

Custom frequency range with custom axis using image file:
	
	axisfile=myaxis.png:basefreq=40:endfreq=10000


=back



=head2 showfreqs


Convert input audio to video output representing the audio power spectrum.
Audio amplitude is on Y-axis while frequency is on X-axis.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<size, s>

Specify size of video. For the syntax of this option, check the
B<"Video size" section in the ffmpeg-utils manual>.
Default is C<1024x512>.


=item B<mode>

Set display mode.
This set how each frequency bin will be represented.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<line>


=item B<bar>


=item B<dot>


=back

Default is C<bar>.


=item B<ascale>

Set amplitude scale.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<lin>

Linear scale.


=item B<sqrt>

Square root scale.


=item B<cbrt>

Cubic root scale.


=item B<log>

Logarithmic scale.

=back

Default is C<log>.


=item B<fscale>

Set frequency scale.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<lin>

Linear scale.


=item B<log>

Logarithmic scale.


=item B<rlog>

Reverse logarithmic scale.

=back

Default is C<lin>.


=item B<win_size>

Set window size. Allowed range is from 16 to 65536.

Default is C<2048>


=item B<win_func>

Set windowing function.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<rect>


=item B<bartlett>


=item B<hanning>


=item B<hamming>


=item B<blackman>


=item B<welch>


=item B<flattop>


=item B<bharris>


=item B<bnuttall>


=item B<bhann>


=item B<sine>


=item B<nuttall>


=item B<lanczos>


=item B<gauss>


=item B<tukey>


=item B<dolph>


=item B<cauchy>


=item B<parzen>


=item B<poisson>


=item B<bohman>


=back

Default is C<hanning>.


=item B<overlap>

Set window overlap. In range C<[0, 1]>. Default is C<1>,
which means optimal overlap for selected window function will be picked.


=item B<averaging>

Set time averaging. Setting this to 0 will display current maximal peaks.
Default is C<1>, which means time averaging is disabled.


=item B<colors>

Specify list of colors separated by space or by '|' which will be used to
draw channel frequencies. Unrecognized or missing colors will be replaced
by white color.


=item B<cmode>

Set channel display mode.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<combined>


=item B<separate>


=back

Default is C<combined>.


=item B<minamp>

Set minimum amplitude used in C<log> amplitude scaler.


=item B<data>

Set data display mode.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<magnitude>


=item B<phase>


=item B<delay>


=back

Default is C<magnitude>.

=back



=head2 showspatial


Convert stereo input audio to a video output, representing the spatial relationship
between two channels.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<size, s>

Specify the video size for the output. For the syntax of this option, check the
B<"Video size" section in the ffmpeg-utils manual>.
Default value is C<512x512>.


=item B<win_size>

Set window size. Allowed range is from I<1024> to I<65536>. Default size is I<4096>.


=item B<win_func>

Set window function.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<rect>


=item B<bartlett>


=item B<hann>


=item B<hanning>


=item B<hamming>


=item B<blackman>


=item B<welch>


=item B<flattop>


=item B<bharris>


=item B<bnuttall>


=item B<bhann>


=item B<sine>


=item B<nuttall>


=item B<lanczos>


=item B<gauss>


=item B<tukey>


=item B<dolph>


=item B<cauchy>


=item B<parzen>


=item B<poisson>


=item B<bohman>


=back


Default value is C<hann>.


=item B<overlap>

Set ratio of overlap window. Default value is C<0.5>.
When value is C<1> overlap is set to recommended size for specific
window function currently used.

=back




=head2 showspectrum


Convert input audio to a video output, representing the audio frequency
spectrum.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<size, s>

Specify the video size for the output. For the syntax of this option, check the
B<"Video size" section in the ffmpeg-utils manual>.
Default value is C<640x512>.


=item B<slide>

Specify how the spectrum should slide along the window.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<replace>

the samples start again on the left when they reach the right

=item B<scroll>

the samples scroll from right to left

=item B<fullframe>

frames are only produced when the samples reach the right

=item B<rscroll>

the samples scroll from left to right

=back


Default value is C<replace>.


=item B<mode>

Specify display mode.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<combined>

all channels are displayed in the same row

=item B<separate>

all channels are displayed in separate rows

=back


Default value is B<combined>.


=item B<color>

Specify display color mode.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<channel>

each channel is displayed in a separate color

=item B<intensity>

each channel is displayed using the same color scheme

=item B<rainbow>

each channel is displayed using the rainbow color scheme

=item B<moreland>

each channel is displayed using the moreland color scheme

=item B<nebulae>

each channel is displayed using the nebulae color scheme

=item B<fire>

each channel is displayed using the fire color scheme

=item B<fiery>

each channel is displayed using the fiery color scheme

=item B<fruit>

each channel is displayed using the fruit color scheme

=item B<cool>

each channel is displayed using the cool color scheme

=item B<magma>

each channel is displayed using the magma color scheme

=item B<green>

each channel is displayed using the green color scheme

=item B<viridis>

each channel is displayed using the viridis color scheme

=item B<plasma>

each channel is displayed using the plasma color scheme

=item B<cividis>

each channel is displayed using the cividis color scheme

=item B<terrain>

each channel is displayed using the terrain color scheme

=back


Default value is B<channel>.


=item B<scale>

Specify scale used for calculating intensity color values.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<lin>

linear

=item B<sqrt>

square root, default

=item B<cbrt>

cubic root

=item B<log>

logarithmic

=item B<4thrt>

4th root

=item B<5thrt>

5th root

=back


Default value is B<sqrt>.


=item B<fscale>

Specify frequency scale.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<lin>

linear

=item B<log>

logarithmic

=back


Default value is B<lin>.


=item B<saturation>

Set saturation modifier for displayed colors. Negative values provide
alternative color scheme. C<0> is no saturation at all.
Saturation must be in [-10.0, 10.0] range.
Default value is C<1>.


=item B<win_func>

Set window function.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<rect>


=item B<bartlett>


=item B<hann>


=item B<hanning>


=item B<hamming>


=item B<blackman>


=item B<welch>


=item B<flattop>


=item B<bharris>


=item B<bnuttall>


=item B<bhann>


=item B<sine>


=item B<nuttall>


=item B<lanczos>


=item B<gauss>


=item B<tukey>


=item B<dolph>


=item B<cauchy>


=item B<parzen>


=item B<poisson>


=item B<bohman>


=back


Default value is C<hann>.


=item B<orientation>

Set orientation of time vs frequency axis. Can be C<vertical> or
C<horizontal>. Default is C<vertical>.


=item B<overlap>

Set ratio of overlap window. Default value is C<0>.
When value is C<1> overlap is set to recommended size for specific
window function currently used.


=item B<gain>

Set scale gain for calculating intensity color values.
Default value is C<1>.


=item B<data>

Set which data to display. Can be C<magnitude>, default or C<phase>.


=item B<rotation>

Set color rotation, must be in [-1.0, 1.0] range.
Default value is C<0>.


=item B<start>

Set start frequency from which to display spectrogram. Default is C<0>.


=item B<stop>

Set stop frequency to which to display spectrogram. Default is C<0>.


=item B<fps>

Set upper frame rate limit. Default is C<auto>, unlimited.


=item B<legend>

Draw time and frequency axes and legends. Default is disabled.

=back


The usage is very similar to the showwaves filter; see the examples in that
section.


=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Large window with logarithmic color scaling:
	
	showspectrum=s=1280x480:scale=log



=item *

Complete example for a colored and sliding spectrum per channel using B<ffplay>:
	
	ffplay -f lavfi 'amovie=input.mp3, asplit [a][out1];
	             [a] showspectrum=mode=separate:color=intensity:slide=1:scale=cbrt [out0]'


=back



=head2 showspectrumpic


Convert input audio to a single video frame, representing the audio frequency
spectrum.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<size, s>

Specify the video size for the output. For the syntax of this option, check the
B<"Video size" section in the ffmpeg-utils manual>.
Default value is C<4096x2048>.


=item B<mode>

Specify display mode.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<combined>

all channels are displayed in the same row

=item B<separate>

all channels are displayed in separate rows

=back

Default value is B<combined>.


=item B<color>

Specify display color mode.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<channel>

each channel is displayed in a separate color

=item B<intensity>

each channel is displayed using the same color scheme

=item B<rainbow>

each channel is displayed using the rainbow color scheme

=item B<moreland>

each channel is displayed using the moreland color scheme

=item B<nebulae>

each channel is displayed using the nebulae color scheme

=item B<fire>

each channel is displayed using the fire color scheme

=item B<fiery>

each channel is displayed using the fiery color scheme

=item B<fruit>

each channel is displayed using the fruit color scheme

=item B<cool>

each channel is displayed using the cool color scheme

=item B<magma>

each channel is displayed using the magma color scheme

=item B<green>

each channel is displayed using the green color scheme

=item B<viridis>

each channel is displayed using the viridis color scheme

=item B<plasma>

each channel is displayed using the plasma color scheme

=item B<cividis>

each channel is displayed using the cividis color scheme

=item B<terrain>

each channel is displayed using the terrain color scheme

=back

Default value is B<intensity>.


=item B<scale>

Specify scale used for calculating intensity color values.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<lin>

linear

=item B<sqrt>

square root, default

=item B<cbrt>

cubic root

=item B<log>

logarithmic

=item B<4thrt>

4th root

=item B<5thrt>

5th root

=back

Default value is B<log>.


=item B<fscale>

Specify frequency scale.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<lin>

linear

=item B<log>

logarithmic

=back


Default value is B<lin>.


=item B<saturation>

Set saturation modifier for displayed colors. Negative values provide
alternative color scheme. C<0> is no saturation at all.
Saturation must be in [-10.0, 10.0] range.
Default value is C<1>.


=item B<win_func>

Set window function.

It accepts the following values:

=over 4


=item B<rect>


=item B<bartlett>


=item B<hann>


=item B<hanning>


=item B<hamming>


=item B<blackman>


=item B<welch>


=item B<flattop>


=item B<bharris>


=item B<bnuttall>


=item B<bhann>


=item B<sine>


=item B<nuttall>


=item B<lanczos>


=item B<gauss>


=item B<tukey>


=item B<dolph>


=item B<cauchy>


=item B<parzen>


=item B<poisson>


=item B<bohman>


=back

Default value is C<hann>.


=item B<orientation>

Set orientation of time vs frequency axis. Can be C<vertical> or
C<horizontal>. Default is C<vertical>.


=item B<gain>

Set scale gain for calculating intensity color values.
Default value is C<1>.


=item B<legend>

Draw time and frequency axes and legends. Default is enabled.


=item B<rotation>

Set color rotation, must be in [-1.0, 1.0] range.
Default value is C<0>.


=item B<start>

Set start frequency from which to display spectrogram. Default is C<0>.


=item B<stop>

Set stop frequency to which to display spectrogram. Default is C<0>.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Extract an audio spectrogram of a whole audio track
in a 1024x1024 picture using B<ffmpeg>:
	
	ffmpeg -i audio.flac -lavfi showspectrumpic=s=1024x1024 spectrogram.png


=back



=head2 showvolume


Convert input audio volume to a video output.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<rate, r>

Set video rate.


=item B<b>

Set border width, allowed range is [0, 5]. Default is 1.


=item B<w>

Set channel width, allowed range is [80, 8192]. Default is 400.


=item B<h>

Set channel height, allowed range is [1, 900]. Default is 20.


=item B<f>

Set fade, allowed range is [0, 1]. Default is 0.95.


=item B<c>

Set volume color expression.

The expression can use the following variables:


=over 4


=item B<VOLUME>

Current max volume of channel in dB.


=item B<PEAK>

Current peak.


=item B<CHANNEL>

Current channel number, starting from 0.

=back



=item B<t>

If set, displays channel names. Default is enabled.


=item B<v>

If set, displays volume values. Default is enabled.


=item B<o>

Set orientation, can be horizontal: C<h> or vertical: C<v>,
default is C<h>.


=item B<s>

Set step size, allowed range is [0, 5]. Default is 0, which means
step is disabled.


=item B<p>

Set background opacity, allowed range is [0, 1]. Default is 0.


=item B<m>

Set metering mode, can be peak: C<p> or rms: C<r>,
default is C<p>.


=item B<ds>

Set display scale, can be linear: C<lin> or log: C<log>,
default is C<lin>.


=item B<dm>

In second.
If set to E<gt> 0., display a line for the max level
in the previous seconds.
default is disabled: C<0.>


=item B<dmc>

The color of the max line. Use when C<dm> option is set to E<gt> 0.
default is: C<orange>

=back



=head2 showwaves


Convert input audio to a video output, representing the samples waves.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<size, s>

Specify the video size for the output. For the syntax of this option, check the
B<"Video size" section in the ffmpeg-utils manual>.
Default value is C<600x240>.


=item B<mode>

Set display mode.

Available values are:

=over 4


=item B<point>

Draw a point for each sample.


=item B<line>

Draw a vertical line for each sample.


=item B<p2p>

Draw a point for each sample and a line between them.


=item B<cline>

Draw a centered vertical line for each sample.

=back


Default value is C<point>.


=item B<n>

Set the number of samples which are printed on the same column. A
larger value will decrease the frame rate. Must be a positive
integer. This option can be set only if the value for I<rate>
is not explicitly specified.


=item B<rate, r>

Set the (approximate) output frame rate. This is done by setting the
option I<n>. Default value is "25".


=item B<split_channels>

Set if channels should be drawn separately or overlap. Default value is 0.


=item B<colors>

Set colors separated by '|' which are going to be used for drawing of each channel.


=item B<scale>

Set amplitude scale.

Available values are:

=over 4


=item B<lin>

Linear.


=item B<log>

Logarithmic.


=item B<sqrt>

Square root.


=item B<cbrt>

Cubic root.

=back


Default is linear.


=item B<draw>

Set the draw mode. This is mostly useful to set for high I<n>.

Available values are:

=over 4


=item B<scale>

Scale pixel values for each drawn sample.


=item B<full>

Draw every sample directly.

=back


Default value is C<scale>.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Output the input file audio and the corresponding video representation
at the same time:
	
	amovie=a.mp3,asplit[out0],showwaves[out1]



=item *

Create a synthetic signal and show it with showwaves, forcing a
frame rate of 30 frames per second:
	
	aevalsrc=sin(1*2*PI*t)*sin(880*2*PI*t):cos(2*PI*200*t),asplit[out0],showwaves=r=30[out1]


=back



=head2 showwavespic


Convert input audio to a single video frame, representing the samples waves.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<size, s>

Specify the video size for the output. For the syntax of this option, check the
B<"Video size" section in the ffmpeg-utils manual>.
Default value is C<600x240>.


=item B<split_channels>

Set if channels should be drawn separately or overlap. Default value is 0.


=item B<colors>

Set colors separated by '|' which are going to be used for drawing of each channel.


=item B<scale>

Set amplitude scale.

Available values are:

=over 4


=item B<lin>

Linear.


=item B<log>

Logarithmic.


=item B<sqrt>

Square root.


=item B<cbrt>

Cubic root.

=back


Default is linear.


=item B<draw>

Set the draw mode.

Available values are:

=over 4


=item B<scale>

Scale pixel values for each drawn sample.


=item B<full>

Draw every sample directly.

=back


Default value is C<scale>.


=item B<filter>

Set the filter mode.

Available values are:

=over 4


=item B<average>

Use average samples values for each drawn sample.


=item B<peak>

Use peak samples values for each drawn sample.

=back


Default value is C<average>.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Extract a channel split representation of the wave form of a whole audio track
in a 1024x800 picture using B<ffmpeg>:
	
	ffmpeg -i audio.flac -lavfi showwavespic=split_channels=1:s=1024x800 waveform.png


=back



=head2 sidedata, asidedata


Delete frame side data, or select frames based on it.

This filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<mode>

Set mode of operation of the filter.

Can be one of the following:


=over 4


=item B<select>

Select every frame with side data of C<type>.


=item B<delete>

Delete side data of C<type>. If C<type> is not set, delete all side
data in the frame.


=back



=item B<type>

Set side data type used with all modes. Must be set for C<select> mode. For
the list of frame side data types, refer to the C<AVFrameSideDataType> enum
in F<libavutil/frame.h>. For example, to choose
C<AV_FRAME_DATA_PANSCAN> side data, you must specify C<PANSCAN>.


=back



=head2 spectrumsynth


Synthesize audio from 2 input video spectrums, first input stream represents
magnitude across time and second represents phase across time.
The filter will transform from frequency domain as displayed in videos back
to time domain as presented in audio output.

This filter is primarily created for reversing processed B<showspectrum>
filter outputs, but can synthesize sound from other spectrograms too.
But in such case results are going to be poor if the phase data is not
available, because in such cases phase data need to be recreated, usually
it's just recreated from random noise.
For best results use gray only output (C<channel> color mode in
B<showspectrum> filter) and C<log> scale for magnitude video and
C<lin> scale for phase video. To produce phase, for 2nd video, use
C<data> option. Inputs videos should generally use C<fullframe>
slide mode as that saves resources needed for decoding video.

The filter accepts the following options:


=over 4


=item B<sample_rate>

Specify sample rate of output audio, the sample rate of audio from which
spectrum was generated may differ.


=item B<channels>

Set number of channels represented in input video spectrums.


=item B<scale>

Set scale which was used when generating magnitude input spectrum.
Can be C<lin> or C<log>. Default is C<log>.


=item B<slide>

Set slide which was used when generating inputs spectrums.
Can be C<replace>, C<scroll>, C<fullframe> or C<rscroll>.
Default is C<fullframe>.


=item B<win_func>

Set window function used for resynthesis.


=item B<overlap>

Set window overlap. In range C<[0, 1]>. Default is C<1>,
which means optimal overlap for selected window function will be picked.


=item B<orientation>

Set orientation of input videos. Can be C<vertical> or C<horizontal>.
Default is C<vertical>.

=back



=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

First create magnitude and phase videos from audio, assuming audio is stereo with 44100 sample rate,
then resynthesize videos back to audio with spectrumsynth:
	
	ffmpeg -i input.flac -lavfi showspectrum=mode=separate:scale=log:overlap=0.875:color=channel:slide=fullframe:data=magnitude -an -c:v rawvideo magnitude.nut
	ffmpeg -i input.flac -lavfi showspectrum=mode=separate:scale=lin:overlap=0.875:color=channel:slide=fullframe:data=phase -an -c:v rawvideo phase.nut
	ffmpeg -i magnitude.nut -i phase.nut -lavfi spectrumsynth=channels=2:sample_rate=44100:win_func=hann:overlap=0.875:slide=fullframe output.flac


=back



=head2 split, asplit


Split input into several identical outputs.

C<asplit> works with audio input, C<split> with video.

The filter accepts a single parameter which specifies the number of outputs. If
unspecified, it defaults to 2.


=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Create two separate outputs from the same input:
	
	[in] split [out0][out1]



=item *

To create 3 or more outputs, you need to specify the number of
outputs, like in:
	
	[in] asplit=3 [out0][out1][out2]



=item *

Create two separate outputs from the same input, one cropped and
one padded:
	
	[in] split [splitout1][splitout2];
	[splitout1] crop=100:100:0:0    [cropout];
	[splitout2] pad=200:200:100:100 [padout];



=item *

Create 5 copies of the input audio with B<ffmpeg>:
	
	ffmpeg -i INPUT -filter_complex asplit=5 OUTPUT


=back



=head2 zmq, azmq


Receive commands sent through a libzmq client, and forward them to
filters in the filtergraph.

C<zmq> and C<azmq> work as a pass-through filters. C<zmq>
must be inserted between two video filters, C<azmq> between two
audio filters. Both are capable to send messages to any filter type.

To enable these filters you need to install the libzmq library and
headers and configure FFmpeg with C<--enable-libzmq>.

For more information about libzmq see:
E<lt>B<http://www.zeromq.org/>E<gt>

The C<zmq> and C<azmq> filters work as a libzmq server, which
receives messages sent through a network interface defined by the
B<bind_address> (or the abbreviation "B<b>") option.
Default value of this option is F<tcp://localhost:5555>. You may
want to alter this value to your needs, but do not forget to escape any
':' signs (see B<filtergraph escaping>).

The received message must be in the form:
	
	<TARGET> <COMMAND> [<ARG>]


I<TARGET> specifies the target of the command, usually the name of
the filter class or a specific filter instance name. The default
filter instance name uses the pattern B<Parsed_E<lt>filter_nameE<gt>_E<lt>indexE<gt>>,
but you can override this by using the B<filter_name@id> syntax
(see B<Filtergraph syntax>).

I<COMMAND> specifies the name of the command for the target filter.

I<ARG> is optional and specifies the optional argument list for the
given I<COMMAND>.

Upon reception, the message is processed and the corresponding command
is injected into the filtergraph. Depending on the result, the filter
will send a reply to the client, adopting the format:
	
	<ERROR_CODE> <ERROR_REASON>
	<MESSAGE>


I<MESSAGE> is optional.


=head3 Examples


Look at F<tools/zmqsend> for an example of a zmq client which can
be used to send commands processed by these filters.

Consider the following filtergraph generated by B<ffplay>.
In this example the last overlay filter has an instance name. All other
filters will have default instance names.

	
	ffplay -dumpgraph 1 -f lavfi "
	color=s=100x100:c=red  [l];
	color=s=100x100:c=blue [r];
	nullsrc=s=200x100, zmq [bg];
	[bg][l]   overlay     [bg+l];
	[bg+l][r] overlay@my=x=100 "


To change the color of the left side of the video, the following
command can be used:
	
	echo Parsed_color_0 c yellow | tools/zmqsend


To change the right side:
	
	echo Parsed_color_1 c pink | tools/zmqsend


To change the position of the right side:
	
	echo overlay@my x 150 | tools/zmqsend





=head1 MULTIMEDIA SOURCES


Below is a description of the currently available multimedia sources.


=head2 amovie


This is the same as B<movie> source, except it selects an audio
stream by default.



=head2 movie


Read audio and/or video stream(s) from a movie container.

It accepts the following parameters:


=over 4


=item B<filename>

The name of the resource to read (not necessarily a file; it can also be a
device or a stream accessed through some protocol).


=item B<format_name, f>

Specifies the format assumed for the movie to read, and can be either
the name of a container or an input device. If not specified, the
format is guessed from I<movie_name> or by probing.


=item B<seek_point, sp>

Specifies the seek point in seconds. The frames will be output
starting from this seek point. The parameter is evaluated with
C<av_strtod>, so the numerical value may be suffixed by an IS
postfix. The default value is "0".


=item B<streams, s>

Specifies the streams to read. Several streams can be specified,
separated by "+". The source will then have as many outputs, in the
same order. The syntax is explained in the B<"Stream specifiers"
section in the ffmpeg manual>. Two special names, "dv" and "da" specify
respectively the default (best suited) video and audio stream. Default
is "dv", or "da" if the filter is called as "amovie".


=item B<stream_index, si>

Specifies the index of the video stream to read. If the value is -1,
the most suitable video stream will be automatically selected. The default
value is "-1". Deprecated. If the filter is called "amovie", it will select
audio instead of video.


=item B<loop>

Specifies how many times to read the stream in sequence.
If the value is 0, the stream will be looped infinitely.
Default value is "1".

Note that when the movie is looped the source timestamps are not
changed, so it will generate non monotonically increasing timestamps.


=item B<discontinuity>

Specifies the time difference between frames above which the point is
considered a timestamp discontinuity which is removed by adjusting the later
timestamps.

=back


It allows overlaying a second video on top of the main input of
a filtergraph, as shown in this graph:
	
	input -----------> deltapts0 --> overlay --> output
	                                    ^
	                                    |
	movie --> scale--> deltapts1 -------+


=head3 Examples



=over 4


=item *

Skip 3.2 seconds from the start of the AVI file in.avi, and overlay it
on top of the input labelled "in":
	
	movie=in.avi:seek_point=3.2, scale=180:-1, setpts=PTS-STARTPTS [over];
	[in] setpts=PTS-STARTPTS [main];
	[main][over] overlay=16:16 [out]



=item *

Read from a video4linux2 device, and overlay it on top of the input
labelled "in":
	
	movie=/dev/video0:f=video4linux2, scale=180:-1, setpts=PTS-STARTPTS [over];
	[in] setpts=PTS-STARTPTS [main];
	[main][over] overlay=16:16 [out]



=item *

Read the first video stream and the audio stream with id 0x81 from
dvd.vob; the video is connected to the pad named "video" and the audio is
connected to the pad named "audio":
	
	movie=dvd.vob:s=v:0+#0x81 [video] [audio]


=back



=head3 Commands


Both movie and amovie support the following commands:

=over 4


=item B<seek>

Perform seek using "av_seek_frame".
The syntax is: seek I<stream_index>|I<timestamp>|I<flags>

=over 4


=item *

I<stream_index>: If stream_index is -1, a default
stream is selected, and I<timestamp> is automatically converted
from AV_TIME_BASE units to the stream specific time_base.

=item *

I<timestamp>: Timestamp in AVStream.time_base units
or, if no stream is specified, in AV_TIME_BASE units.

=item *

I<flags>: Flags which select direction and seeking mode.

=back



=item B<get_duration>

Get movie duration in AV_TIME_BASE units.


=back



=head1 EXTERNAL LIBRARIES


FFmpeg can be hooked up with a number of external libraries to add support
for more formats. None of them are used by default, their use has to be
explicitly requested by passing the appropriate flags to
B<./configure>.


=head2 Alliance for Open Media (AOM)


FFmpeg can make use of the AOM library for AV1 decoding and encoding.

Go to E<lt>B<http://aomedia.org/>E<gt> and follow the instructions for
installing the library. Then pass C<--enable-libaom> to configure to
enable it.


=head2 AMD AMF/VCE


FFmpeg can use the AMD Advanced Media Framework library
for accelerated H.264 and HEVC(only windows) encoding on hardware with Video Coding Engine (VCE).

To enable support you must obtain the AMF framework header files(version 1.4.9+) from
E<lt>B<https://github.com/GPUOpen-LibrariesAndSDKs/AMF.git>E<gt>.

Create an C<AMF/> directory in the system include path.
Copy the contents of C<AMF/amf/public/include/> into that directory.
Then configure FFmpeg with C<--enable-amf>.

Initialization of amf encoder occurs in this order:
1) trying to initialize through dx11(only windows)
2) trying to initialize through dx9(only windows)
3) trying to initialize through vulkan

To use h.264(AMD VCE) encoder on linux amdgru-pro version 19.20+ and amf-amdgpu-pro
package(amdgru-pro contains, but does not install automatically) are required.

This driver can be installed using amdgpu-pro-install script in official amd driver archive.


=head2 AviSynth


FFmpeg can read AviSynth scripts as input. To enable support, pass
C<--enable-avisynth> to configure after installing the headers
provided by E<lt>B<https://github.com/AviSynth/AviSynthPlus>E<gt>.
AviSynth+ can be configured to install only the headers by either
passing C<-DHEADERS_ONLY:bool=on> to the normal CMake-based build
system, or by using the supplied C<GNUmakefile>.

For Windows, supported AviSynth variants are
E<lt>B<http://avisynth.nl>E<gt> for 32-bit builds and
E<lt>B<http://avisynth.nl/index.php/AviSynth+>E<gt> for 32-bit and 64-bit builds.

For Linux, macOS, and BSD, the only supported AviSynth variant is
E<lt>B<https://github.com/AviSynth/AviSynthPlus>E<gt>, starting with version 3.5.


=over 4

In 2016, AviSynth+ added support for building with GCC. However, due to
the eccentricities of Windows' calling conventions, 32-bit GCC builds
of AviSynth+ are not compatible with typical 32-bit builds of FFmpeg.

By default, FFmpeg assumes compatibility with 32-bit MSVC builds of
AviSynth+ since that is the most widely-used and entrenched build
configuration.  Users can override this and enable support for 32-bit
GCC builds of AviSynth+ by passing C<-DAVSC_WIN32_GCC32> to
C<--extra-cflags> when configuring FFmpeg.

64-bit builds of FFmpeg are not affected, and can use either MSVC or
GCC builds of AviSynth+ without any special flags.

=back



=over 4

AviSynth(+) is loaded dynamically.  Distributors can build FFmpeg
with C<--enable-avisynth>, and the binaries will work regardless
of the end user having AviSynth installed.  If/when an end user
would like to use AviSynth scripts, then they can install AviSynth(+)
and FFmpeg will be able to find and use it to open scripts.

=back



=head2 Chromaprint


FFmpeg can make use of the Chromaprint library for generating audio fingerprints.
Pass C<--enable-chromaprint> to configure to
enable it. See E<lt>B<https://acoustid.org/chromaprint>E<gt>.


=head2 codec2


FFmpeg can make use of the codec2 library for codec2 decoding and encoding.
There is currently no native decoder, so libcodec2 must be used for decoding.

Go to E<lt>B<http://freedv.org/>E<gt>, download "Codec 2 source archive".
Build and install using CMake. Debian users can install the libcodec2-dev package instead.
Once libcodec2 is installed you can pass C<--enable-libcodec2> to configure to enable it.

The easiest way to use codec2 is with .c2 files, since they contain the mode information required for decoding.
To encode such a file, use a .c2 file extension and give the libcodec2 encoder the -mode option:
C<ffmpeg -i input.wav -mode 700C output.c2>.
Playback is as simple as C<ffplay output.c2>.
For a list of supported modes, run C<ffmpeg -h encoder=libcodec2>.
Raw codec2 files are also supported.
To make sense of them the mode in use needs to be specified as a format option:
C<ffmpeg -f codec2raw -mode 1300 -i input.raw output.wav>.


=head2 dav1d


FFmpeg can make use of the dav1d library for AV1 video decoding.

Go to E<lt>B<https://code.videolan.org/videolan/dav1d>E<gt> and follow the instructions for
installing the library. Then pass C<--enable-libdav1d> to configure to enable it.


=head2 davs2


FFmpeg can make use of the davs2 library for AVS2-P2/IEEE1857.4 video decoding.

Go to E<lt>B<https://github.com/pkuvcl/davs2>E<gt> and follow the instructions for
installing the library. Then pass C<--enable-libdavs2> to configure to
enable it.


=over 4

libdavs2 is under the GNU Public License Version 2 or later
(see E<lt>B<http://www.gnu.org/licenses/old-licenses/gpl-2.0.html>E<gt> for
details), you must upgrade FFmpeg's license to GPL in order to use it.

=back



=head2 uavs3d


FFmpeg can make use of the uavs3d library for AVS3-P2/IEEE1857.10 video decoding.

Go to E<lt>B<https://github.com/uavs3/uavs3d>E<gt> and follow the instructions for
installing the library. Then pass C<--enable-libuavs3d> to configure to
enable it.


=head2 Game Music Emu


FFmpeg can make use of the Game Music Emu library to read audio from supported video game
music file formats. Pass C<--enable-libgme> to configure to
enable it. See E<lt>B<https://bitbucket.org/mpyne/game-music-emu/overview>E<gt>.


=head2 Intel QuickSync Video


FFmpeg can use Intel QuickSync Video (QSV) for accelerated decoding and encoding
of multiple codecs. To use QSV, FFmpeg must be linked against the C<libmfx>
dispatcher, which loads the actual decoding libraries.

The dispatcher is open source and can be downloaded from
E<lt>B<https://github.com/lu-zero/mfx_dispatch.git>E<gt>. FFmpeg needs to be configured
with the C<--enable-libmfx> option and C<pkg-config> needs to be able to
locate the dispatcher's C<.pc> files.


=head2 Kvazaar


FFmpeg can make use of the Kvazaar library for HEVC encoding.

Go to E<lt>B<https://github.com/ultravideo/kvazaar>E<gt> and follow the
instructions for installing the library. Then pass
C<--enable-libkvazaar> to configure to enable it.


=head2 LAME


FFmpeg can make use of the LAME library for MP3 encoding.

Go to E<lt>B<http://lame.sourceforge.net/>E<gt> and follow the
instructions for installing the library.
Then pass C<--enable-libmp3lame> to configure to enable it.


=head2 libilbc


iLBC is a narrowband speech codec that has been made freely available
by Google as part of the WebRTC project. libilbc is a packaging friendly
copy of the iLBC codec. FFmpeg can make use of the libilbc library for
iLBC decoding and encoding.

Go to E<lt>B<https://github.com/TimothyGu/libilbc>E<gt> and follow the instructions for
installing the library. Then pass C<--enable-libilbc> to configure to
enable it.


=head2 libvpx


FFmpeg can make use of the libvpx library for VP8/VP9 decoding and encoding.

Go to E<lt>B<http://www.webmproject.org/>E<gt> and follow the instructions for
installing the library. Then pass C<--enable-libvpx> to configure to
enable it.


=head2 ModPlug


FFmpeg can make use of this library, originating in Modplug-XMMS, to read from MOD-like music files.
See E<lt>B<https://github.com/Konstanty/libmodplug>E<gt>. Pass C<--enable-libmodplug> to configure to
enable it.


=head2 OpenCORE, VisualOn, and Fraunhofer libraries


Spun off Google Android sources, OpenCore, VisualOn and Fraunhofer
libraries provide encoders for a number of audio codecs.


=over 4

OpenCORE and VisualOn libraries are under the Apache License 2.0
(see E<lt>B<http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0>E<gt> for details), which is
incompatible to the LGPL version 2.1 and GPL version 2. You have to
upgrade FFmpeg's license to LGPL version 3 (or if you have enabled
GPL components, GPL version 3) by passing C<--enable-version3> to configure in
order to use it.

The license of the Fraunhofer AAC library is incompatible with the GPL.
Therefore, for GPL builds, you have to pass C<--enable-nonfree> to
configure in order to use it. To the best of our knowledge, it is
compatible with the LGPL.

=back



=head3 OpenCORE AMR


FFmpeg can make use of the OpenCORE libraries for AMR-NB
decoding/encoding and AMR-WB decoding.

Go to E<lt>B<http://sourceforge.net/projects/opencore-amr/>E<gt> and follow the
instructions for installing the libraries.
Then pass C<--enable-libopencore-amrnb> and/or
C<--enable-libopencore-amrwb> to configure to enable them.


=head3 VisualOn AMR-WB encoder library


FFmpeg can make use of the VisualOn AMR-WBenc library for AMR-WB encoding.

Go to E<lt>B<http://sourceforge.net/projects/opencore-amr/>E<gt> and follow the
instructions for installing the library.
Then pass C<--enable-libvo-amrwbenc> to configure to enable it.


=head3 Fraunhofer AAC library


FFmpeg can make use of the Fraunhofer AAC library for AAC decoding & encoding.

Go to E<lt>B<http://sourceforge.net/projects/opencore-amr/>E<gt> and follow the
instructions for installing the library.
Then pass C<--enable-libfdk-aac> to configure to enable it.


=head2 OpenH264


FFmpeg can make use of the OpenH264 library for H.264 decoding and encoding.

Go to E<lt>B<http://www.openh264.org/>E<gt> and follow the instructions for
installing the library. Then pass C<--enable-libopenh264> to configure to
enable it.

For decoding, this library is much more limited than the built-in decoder
in libavcodec; currently, this library lacks support for decoding B-frames
and some other main/high profile features. (It currently only supports
constrained baseline profile and CABAC.) Using it is mostly useful for
testing and for taking advantage of Cisco's patent portfolio license
(E<lt>B<http://www.openh264.org/BINARY_LICENSE.txt>E<gt>).


=head2 OpenJPEG


FFmpeg can use the OpenJPEG libraries for decoding/encoding J2K videos.  Go to
E<lt>B<http://www.openjpeg.org/>E<gt> to get the libraries and follow the installation
instructions.  To enable using OpenJPEG in FFmpeg, pass C<--enable-libopenjpeg> to
F<./configure>.


=head2 rav1e


FFmpeg can make use of rav1e (Rust AV1 Encoder) via its C bindings to encode videos.
Go to E<lt>B<https://github.com/xiph/rav1e/>E<gt> and follow the instructions to build
the C library. To enable using rav1e in FFmpeg, pass C<--enable-librav1e>
to F<./configure>.


=head2 SVT-AV1


FFmpeg can make use of the Scalable Video Technology for AV1 library for AV1 encoding.

Go to E<lt>B<https://github.com/OpenVisualCloud/SVT-AV1/>E<gt> and follow the instructions
for installing the library. Then pass C<--enable-libsvtav1> to configure to
enable it.


=head2 TwoLAME


FFmpeg can make use of the TwoLAME library for MP2 encoding.

Go to E<lt>B<http://www.twolame.org/>E<gt> and follow the
instructions for installing the library.
Then pass C<--enable-libtwolame> to configure to enable it.


=head2 VapourSynth


FFmpeg can read VapourSynth scripts as input. To enable support, pass
C<--enable-vapoursynth> to configure. Vapoursynth is detected via
C<pkg-config>. Versions 42 or greater supported.
See E<lt>B<http://www.vapoursynth.com/>E<gt>.

Due to security concerns, Vapoursynth scripts will not
be autodetected so the input format has to be forced. For ff* CLI tools,
add C<-f vapoursynth> before the input C<-i yourscript.vpy>.


=head2 x264


FFmpeg can make use of the x264 library for H.264 encoding.

Go to E<lt>B<http://www.videolan.org/developers/x264.html>E<gt> and follow the
instructions for installing the library. Then pass C<--enable-libx264> to
configure to enable it.


=over 4

x264 is under the GNU Public License Version 2 or later
(see E<lt>B<http://www.gnu.org/licenses/old-licenses/gpl-2.0.html>E<gt> for
details), you must upgrade FFmpeg's license to GPL in order to use it.

=back



=head2 x265


FFmpeg can make use of the x265 library for HEVC encoding.

Go to E<lt>B<http://x265.org/developers.html>E<gt> and follow the instructions
for installing the library. Then pass C<--enable-libx265> to configure
to enable it.


=over 4

x265 is under the GNU Public License Version 2 or later
(see E<lt>B<http://www.gnu.org/licenses/old-licenses/gpl-2.0.html>E<gt> for
details), you must upgrade FFmpeg's license to GPL in order to use it.

=back



=head2 xavs


FFmpeg can make use of the xavs library for AVS encoding.

Go to E<lt>B<http://xavs.sf.net/>E<gt> and follow the instructions for
installing the library. Then pass C<--enable-libxavs> to configure to
enable it.


=head2 xavs2


FFmpeg can make use of the xavs2 library for AVS2-P2/IEEE1857.4 video encoding.

Go to E<lt>B<https://github.com/pkuvcl/xavs2>E<gt> and follow the instructions for
installing the library. Then pass C<--enable-libxavs2> to configure to
enable it.


=over 4

libxavs2 is under the GNU Public License Version 2 or later
(see E<lt>B<http://www.gnu.org/licenses/old-licenses/gpl-2.0.html>E<gt> for
details), you must upgrade FFmpeg's license to GPL in order to use it.

=back



=head2 ZVBI


ZVBI is a VBI decoding library which can be used by FFmpeg to decode DVB
teletext pages and DVB teletext subtitles.

Go to E<lt>B<http://sourceforge.net/projects/zapping/>E<gt> and follow the instructions for
installing the library. Then pass C<--enable-libzvbi> to configure to
enable it.


=head1 SUPPORTED FILE FORMATS


You can use the C<-formats> and C<-codecs> options to have an exhaustive list.


=head2 File Formats


FFmpeg supports the following file formats through the C<libavformat>
library:


=over 4


=item B<Name  :  Encoding @tab Decoding @tab Comments>


=item B<3dostr                     :    @tab X>


=item B<4xm                        :    @tab X>

    @tab 4X Technologies format, used in some games.

=item B<8088flex TMV               :    @tab X>


=item B<AAX                        :    @tab X>

    @tab Audible Enhanced Audio format, used in audiobooks.

=item B<AA                         :    @tab X>

    @tab Audible Format 2, 3, and 4, used in audiobooks.

=item B<ACT Voice                  :    @tab X>

    @tab contains G.729 audio

=item B<Adobe Filmstrip            :  X @tab X>


=item B<Audio IFF (AIFF)           :  X @tab X>


=item B<American Laser Games MM    :    @tab X>

    @tab Multimedia format used in games like Mad Dog McCree.

=item B<3GPP AMR                   :  X @tab X>


=item B<Amazing Studio Packed Animation File   :    @tab X>

    @tab Multimedia format used in game Heart Of Darkness.

=item B<Apple HTTP Live Streaming  :    @tab X>


=item B<Artworx Data Format        :    @tab X>


=item B<Interplay ACM              :    @tab X>

    @tab Audio only format used in some Interplay games.

=item B<ADP                        :    @tab X>

    @tab Audio format used on the Nintendo Gamecube.

=item B<AFC                        :    @tab X>

    @tab Audio format used on the Nintendo Gamecube.

=item B<ADS/SS2                    :    @tab X>

    @tab Audio format used on the PS2.

=item B<APNG                       :  X @tab X>


=item B<ASF                        :  X @tab X>

    @tab Advanced / Active Streaming Format.

=item B<AST                        :  X @tab X>

    @tab Audio format used on the Nintendo Wii.

=item B<AVI                        :  X @tab X>


=item B<AviSynth                   :    @tab X>


=item B<AVR                        :    @tab X>

    @tab Audio format used on Mac.

=item B<AVS                        :    @tab X>

    @tab Multimedia format used by the Creature Shock game.

=item B<Beam Software SIFF         :    @tab X>

    @tab Audio and video format used in some games by Beam Software.

=item B<Bethesda Softworks VID     :    @tab X>

=head2 Image Formats


FFmpeg can read and write images for each frame of a video sequence. The
following image formats are supported:


=over 4


=item B<Name  :  Encoding @tab Decoding @tab Comments>


=item B<.Y.U.V        :  X @tab X>

    @tab one raw file per component

    @tab Alias/Wavefront PIX image format

=item B<APNG          :  X @tab X>

    @tab Animated Portable Network Graphics

=item B<BMP           :  X @tab X>

    @tab Microsoft BMP image

=item B<BRender PIX   :    @tab X>

    @tab Argonaut BRender 3D engine image format.

=item B<CRI           :    @tab X>

    @tab Cintel RAW

    @tab Digital Picture Exchange

=item B<EXR           :    @tab X>

    @tab OpenEXR

=item B<FITS          :  X @tab X>

    @tab Flexible Image Transport System

=item B<JPEG          :  X @tab X>

    @tab Progressive JPEG is not supported.

=item B<JPEG 2000     :  X @tab X>


=item B<JPEG-LS       :  X @tab X>


=item B<LJPEG         :  X @tab>

    @tab Lossless JPEG

=item B<MSP           :    @tab X>

    @tab Microsoft Paint image

C<I> means that an integer-only version is available, too (ensures high
performance on systems without hardware floating point support).
